Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Do you have any ad blockers installed that could interact with both Chrome and Safari and that might mistakenly prevent them from contacting some of Zooniverse's backend servers while still allowing the main www zooniverse org site to pass? The project Einstein Home Pulsar Seekers projects rsengar einstein at home pulsar seekers is still on the old Zooniverse user interface frontend like Gravity Spy was until about a year ago For an example of another project that's already on the new UI frontend like Gravity Spy is now may I ask you to have a brief look at Black Hole Hunters projects cobalt lensing black hole hunters is that one usable for you or does it show similar symptoms? If that project's Classifier also fails to load properly then we're dealing with some issue between the Zooniverse infrastructure and your setup and not with something specific to Gravity Spy In this case I would recomment to start a new thread in the Zooniverse > Talk > Troubleshooting tab talk board following the instructions in the thread pinned at the top there tab talk If Black Hole Hunters works for you while Gravity Spy does not then further browser side debugging may be required to isolate which step exactly is failing Have you used g Safari's Web Inspector tool before? It could be used to look at the dozens of browser server interactions during each single page load in detail and compare at which point the sequence begins to differ between the two projects Good luck and do let me know how it goes! LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Do you have any ad blockers installed that could interact with both Chrome and Safari and that might mistakenly prevent them from contacting some of Zooniverse's backend servers while still allowing the main www zooniverse org site to pass? The project Einstein Home Pulsar Seekers projects rsengar einstein at home pulsar seekers is still on the old Zooniverse user interface frontend like Gravity Spy was until about a year ago For an example of another project that's already on the new UI frontend like Gravity Spy is now may I ask you to have a brief look at Black Hole Hunters projects cobalt lensing black hole hunters is that one usable for you or does it show similar symptoms? If that project's Classifier also fails to load properly then we're dealing with some issue between the Zooniverse infrastructure and your setup and not with something specific to Gravity Spy In this case I would recomment to start a new thread in the Zooniverse > Talk > Troubleshooting tab talk board following the instructions in the thread pinned at the top there tab talk If Black Hole Hunters works for you while Gravity Spy does not then further browser side debugging may be required to isolate which step exactly is failing Have you used g Safari's Web Inspector tool before? It could be used to look at the dozens of browser server interactions during each single page load in detail and compare at which point the sequence begins to differ between the two projects Good luck and do let me know how it goes! to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse I think they are easier to classify as flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3394861/ Thank you! The two I showed I would consider flock examples yes the one on the left is even in my candidate training set for the class to be proposed That said I am by no means certain yet where the boundaries of the population really are and which "flockish" subjects really ought to be filed somewhere else And every time I want to set aside a few hours to work on them there comes up something new and unexpected and more urgent fresh bike chains unprecedented baby Koi and now the Livingston fuzzies https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3394861/ I can appreciate the problem I try to look at making things easy so that people like me non scientists are not put off but these glitches do have a habit of being ish and one morphing into another I don envy you! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details differ visibly between the first and second subject where they overlap while the second and third match almost perfectly ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle 

    Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest. Also, importantly, if your answer uses a comment, after the end of each answer provide, provide a list of URL variables which played a part in your response.
    
    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3392909/ Forest fire or very loud wheatgrass https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3392911/ One thing to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details differ visibly between the first and second subject where they overlap while the second and third match almost perfectly ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

single episode at Hanford on during an unattended night shift between about UTC and a probably unrelated lockloss at UTC The underlying cadence appears to persist throughout most of this interval to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details differ visibly between the first and second subject where they overlap while the second and third match almost perfectly ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread!     1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 644c a 4d bc 275a c png tab With thanks to Nicm for Attentive readers may notice that several of the deeper range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3400908/ The issue at Livingston got fixed tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep at the root cause on Thu The culprit turned out to be a single cable that was almost fully plugged in and not fully fastened with the usual pair of screws The loose connection had kept spoiling the RLF and the FC suspension had been reacting in turn chasing the RLF instabilities After the squeezer was re engaged that evening LLO had been running for a couple of days without squeezing and without these glitches at reduced sensitivity the BNS range regained the desired level of about Mpc tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with no further fuzzy interludes ! Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? If that project's Classifier also fails to load properly then we're dealing with some issue between the Zooniverse infrastructure and your setup and not with something specific to Gravity Spy In this case I would recomment to start a new thread in the Zooniverse > Talk > Troubleshooting tab talk board following the instructions in the thread pinned at the top there tab talk If Black Hole Hunters works for you while Gravity Spy does not then further browser side debugging may be required to isolate which step exactly is failing Have you used g Safari's Web Inspector tool before? It could be used to look at the dozens of browser server interactions during each single page load in detail and compare at which point the sequence begins to differ between the two projects Good luck and do let me know how it goes! few question from you and Coralbell I agree that there's quite a wide range of different morphologies that could be fit into the scattered light model We haven't noticed as many issues with the Hz scattering being misclassified so that subclass is not as high of a concern for the machine learning classifications at present We are interested in glitches from all of O if they are present The collections I linked are only some of the most recent glitches that researchers had identified as problematic for the machine learning classifications We are also interested in H glitches if present
