I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? culprit turned out to be a single cable that was almost fully plugged in and not fully fastened with the usual pair of screws The loose connection had kept spoiling the RLF and the FC suspension had sentry version sentry client sentry javascript nextjs 2F Reason CORS request did not succeed Status code null https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3406194/ Welcome to Gravity Spy Talk iambatman and thank you for contributing! Yes the LIGO observatories have been changing a bit faster over the years than our Gravity Spy classification scheme During the ongoing fourth observing run after three years of upgrades they are throwing an unprecedented mix of new glitches at us and at their engineers We're still in the middle of sorting out what's what and trying to figure out how to improve the Gravity Spy Machine Learning component to deal with the new realities You'll meet quite a lot of "None Of The Above" subjects as you advance through the workflows The splendid multi arch Scattered Light glitches as illustrated in the Field Guide were in fact root caused already in late and fixed in January before the end of the third observing run O Scattered Light still causes numerous glitches nowadays but many of them now have their main arches below Hz where we can't see them or as in this case between and Hz with mere fragments of additional arches above Hz The Machine Learning tends to think of these as Low Frequency Burst Personally I've been classifying them as Scattered Light anyway going by how they are caused But it could also be argued that perhaps we should stick with Low Frequency Burst when the obvious noise is confined below Hz where it does less harm and reserve the Scattered Light class for arches protruding well above Hz You'll meet some of those too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3406037/ Update I've managed to load another subject it seems like the not loading is just a side effect and not the main cause Would it be possible for you to check what levels my account has unlocked? The sentry io stuff is unrelated but the StyledLayer sc rmtehz division the last six characters will vary contains the modal "Choose a workflow" popup I conclude from this that some event isn't happening that in the normal course of things ought to dismiss the popup and give way to the Classifier This still leaves a number of possibilities what should have happened in the background includes a Zooniverse API call to load workflow number a request to fetch the workflow's json file with various content details fetching a number of JavaScript resources providing classification related functionality fetching the subject images themselves along with the little thumbnail images for the classifier buttons as well as fetching the project preferences JSON object for the current account and project combination from the API NB I'm not familiar with all the implementation details and I can't check anything on the server side myself moderator privileges extend only to the Talk pages Researcher Kevin crowston has been looking into the matter from the server angle thank you!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle 

    Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest. Also, importantly, if your answer uses a comment, after the end of each answer provide, provide a list of URL variables which played a part in your response.
    
    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? culprit turned out to be a single cable that was almost fully plugged in and not fully fastened with the usual pair of screws The loose connection had kept spoiling the RLF and the FC suspension had sentry version sentry client sentry javascript nextjs 2F Reason CORS request did not succeed Status code null https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3406194/ Welcome to Gravity Spy Talk iambatman and thank you for contributing! Yes the LIGO observatories have been changing a bit faster over the years than our Gravity Spy classification scheme During the ongoing fourth observing run after three years of upgrades they are throwing an unprecedented mix of new glitches at us and at their engineers We're still in the middle of sorting out what's what and trying to figure out how to improve the Gravity Spy Machine Learning component to deal with the new realities You'll meet quite a lot of "None Of The Above" subjects as you advance through the workflows The splendid multi arch Scattered Light glitches as illustrated in the Field Guide were in fact root caused already in late and fixed in January before the end of the third observing run O Scattered Light still causes numerous glitches nowadays but many of them now have their main arches below Hz where we can't see them or as in this case between and Hz with mere fragments of additional arches above Hz The Machine Learning tends to think of these as Low Frequency Burst Personally I've been classifying them as Scattered Light anyway going by how they are caused But it could also be argued that perhaps we should stick with Low Frequency Burst when the obvious noise is confined below Hz where it does less harm and reserve the Scattered Light class for arches protruding well above Hz You'll meet some of those too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3406037/ Update I've managed to load another subject it seems like the not loading is just a side effect and not the main cause Would it be possible for you to check what levels my account has unlocked? The sentry io stuff is unrelated but the StyledLayer sc rmtehz division the last six characters will vary contains the modal "Choose a workflow" popup I conclude from this that some event isn't happening that in the normal course of things ought to dismiss the popup and give way to the Classifier This still leaves a number of possibilities what should have happened in the background includes a Zooniverse API call to load workflow number a request to fetch the workflow's json file with various content details fetching a number of JavaScript resources providing classification related functionality fetching the subject images themselves along with the little thumbnail images for the classifier buttons as well as fetching the project preferences JSON object for the current account and project combination from the API NB I'm not familiar with all the implementation details and I can't check anything on the server side myself moderator privileges extend only to the Talk pages Researcher Kevin crowston has been looking into the matter from the server angle thank you!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle 

    Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest. Also, importantly, if your answer uses a comment, after the end of each answer provide, provide a list of URL variables which played a part in your response.
    
    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? culprit turned out to be a single cable that was almost fully plugged in and not fully fastened with the usual pair of screws The loose connection had kept spoiling the RLF and the FC suspension had sentry version sentry client sentry javascript nextjs 2F Reason CORS request did not succeed Status code null https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3406194/ Welcome to Gravity Spy Talk iambatman and thank you for contributing! Yes the LIGO observatories have been changing a bit faster over the years than our Gravity Spy classification scheme During the ongoing fourth observing run after three years of upgrades they are throwing an unprecedented mix of new glitches at us and at their engineers We're still in the middle of sorting out what's what and trying to figure out how to improve the Gravity Spy Machine Learning component to deal with the new realities You'll meet quite a lot of "None Of The Above" subjects as you advance through the workflows The splendid multi arch Scattered Light glitches as illustrated in the Field Guide were in fact root caused already in late and fixed in January before the end of the third observing run O Scattered Light still causes numerous glitches nowadays but many of them now have their main arches below Hz where we can't see them or as in this case between and Hz with mere fragments of additional arches above Hz The Machine Learning tends to think of these as Low Frequency Burst Personally I've been classifying them as Scattered Light anyway going by how they are caused But it could also be argued that perhaps we should stick with Low Frequency Burst when the obvious noise is confined below Hz where it does less harm and reserve the Scattered Light class for arches protruding well above Hz You'll meet some of those too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3406037/ Update I've managed to load another subject it seems like the not loading is just a side effect and not the main cause Would it be possible for you to check what levels my account has unlocked? The sentry io stuff is unrelated but the StyledLayer sc rmtehz division the last six characters will vary contains the modal "Choose a workflow" popup I conclude from this that some event isn't happening that in the normal course of things ought to dismiss the popup and give way to the Classifier This still leaves a number of possibilities what should have happened in the background includes a Zooniverse API call to load workflow number a request to fetch the workflow's json file with various content details fetching a number of JavaScript resources providing classification related functionality fetching the subject images themselves along with the little thumbnail images for the classifier buttons as well as fetching the project preferences JSON object for the current account and project combination from the API NB I'm not familiar with all the implementation details and I can't check anything on the server side myself moderator privileges extend only to the Talk pages Researcher Kevin crowston has been looking into the matter from the server angle thank you!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle 

    Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest. Also, importantly, if your answer uses a comment, after the end of each answer provide, provide a list of URL variables which played a part in your response.
    
    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. characteristic subjects have a whole row of such successive arches may culminate seconds apart or farther apart depending on whether the driving ground motion reached the pendulum resonance at Hz or https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3410764?comment https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3410766/ For the benefit of future readers since there's no need to preach to the converted I should also mention that you're setting a good example here When using similarity searches to explore one hypothetical or confirmed glitch class it's important to stop every once in a while and take a close look at the marginal cases outliers and probable non examples that have come up among the sim search results in other words to explore the boundaries of the glitch population of interest both from the inside and from the outside It also helps to switch focus every once in a while working with one glitch class for a couple of hours at a time and then proceeding to another and later to a third to keep one's own perception evenly calibrated Looking at only one kind of glitches only from the inside for a week or more at a time would be a recipe for mission creep one would be tempted to subsume more and more stuff that doesn't really belong into the topic of investigation That seems to be a built in drawback of our human bio neural networks https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3410764/ hz line https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3410843/ hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3404344/ These happened only during a few days in late October and only distinct glitches of this kind seem to have been recorded We still don't know what had caused them Around that time there were some issue with uploading fresh subjects to Zooniverse and simultaneously to the Gravity Spy tools tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu which resulted in a number of incomplete uploads and repeat attempts ultimately each of these glitches has ended up on Zooniverse five or six times with different subject numbers while only the final uploads those with 9636xxxx subject numbers have successfully made it into the Similarity Search tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search tool You can use the Similarity Search tool to among other things read out the peak frequency of subject tab the good one of which the present subject is now an extraneous duplicate Hz The incompletely uploaded subjects with numbers between 9287xxxx and 9343xxxx would cause the tool to respond with an error message https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3410843/ P S You may want to start We would focus on the glitch closest to time seconds or dominant at this time when there are different kinds of unrelated glitches in view by coincidence In the present case we're dealing with a compound glitch that lasted rather longer than seconds and where the whole affair should be treated as a single event In fact it's part of an episode at Hanford that lasted more than a day on and it was a new kind of glitch for LIGO then though similar things have happened on a couple of other occasions since and there were enough of them already back in November to earn their own glitch class proposal tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk For now we can classify them as None Of The Above Fun fact The Hanford operators also used the word "fuzzy" although they were referring to what these glitches were doing to the observatory sensitivity not to their appearance in our images It is sometimes hard to tell whether a subject shows a compound glitch group or a chance near coincidence of independently caused glitches years of experience help There are even some cases tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk where ultimately a single cause had been at work interfering with the proper workings of the interferometer in multiple ways and indirectly leading to a multitude of near simultaneous glitches of different types Returning to the present subject The small bright central feature here had indeed rung in at Hz as you can verify by feeding the subject number to the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search close to Hz but not quite there Power Line glitches have been absent at Hanford during the fourth observing run so far as far as I can tell although we've had a number of them from Livingston ER and O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a power line Which reminds me one of these days I'll need to start a collection of those from Livingston during Engineering Run and O4b They often show a tell tale pair of "eyes" There's always some Hz noise present which always needs to be carefully subtracted When there's a sudden brief excess it will be momentarily overcompensated then undercompensated then overcompensated again producing those "eye" features https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/331/3411355/ Thanks for the great answer I too noticed that a similar pattern      Thank you Coralbell for your thoughts! At the moment I don't have much more to say about Cairns while we wait for feedback from the researchers I'll keep working on my enqueued sim search results and adding to my collections as appropriate However it doesn't look like we're going to end up with sufficiently many subjects to build a decent training set the lower limit of subjects for a glitch class proposal exists for a reason Not unless more of these glitches arrive in the coming weeks and months I've already provided links to several collections of subjects that I believe should be classified as Scattered Light so there's not much more to say here either for now I took a serious look at the Hz stuff yesterday and this morning and one lightbulb after another lit up bulb bulb bulb This will turn into a sufficiently long story to be written up elsewhere but again there aren't really enough subjects for a training set Executive summary Yes there's a well defined population of glitches that have attracted Scattered Light mis labelings from the ML It lives near Hz upconversion often produces additional noise near Hz it's practically all from Livingston unrelated to the Hanford glitches near and Hz already mentioned earlier! and it had mostly got fixed by early July so O4b examples are rare https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/729/3399349/ Thank you for the summaries ZngabitanT! Deutsches Museum and the current special exhibition Light and matter tab https www deutsches museum de en museum island programme event licht und materie sponsored and equipped by the Munich Center for Quantum Science and Technology tab https www mcqst de a consortium of university institutes and the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics tab https www mpq mpg de en For example it sounds like a simple exercise to steer a green laser beam into the middle of a bullseye target using two motorized tip tilt mirrors similar to this genuine LIGO guy from here tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep ! pico motorized tip tilt mirror at LLO from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads IMG jpeg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads IMG jpeg It becomes a bit harder when you try to first thread the beam through a motorized iris diaphragm now you don't merely have to hit the middle of the target which can be achieved by adjusting either mirror you have to hit it from the right direction which requires adjusting both mirrors in turns repeatedly Oh and have you ever wondered where the little green nanometer photons are coming from? No storks are involved Rather two near infrared nm photons get together inside a smart little crystal of potassium titanyl phosphate tab https en wikipedia org wiki Potassium titanyl phosphate something that's also used in several places in each LIGO instrument as well as in commercial green laser pointers as a Second Harmonic Generator Like this one tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep although the infrared part remains invisible to our eyes and the crystal itself is hidden inside an enclosure at LIGO but at the exhibition you can watch one in live action ! Our Talk > Help > Resources tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk page links to a whole lot of material For example you may want to skim the article P Nguyen al Environmental Noise in Advanced LIGO Detectors tab https arxiv org pdf PDF arXiv astro ph IM Classical and Quantum Gravity Volume Number written and illustrated for a scientifically interested audience who is not yet familiar with the details of how environmental noise impacts the observatories including producing glitches and what steps are being taken to mitigate it This paper provides a broad general picture For specific subjects the first follow on question is usually whether it's a one of a kind thing or part of a larger population of similar glitches You can feed the Zooniverse subject number to the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search and ask for example for results from interferometers "ifo" H and L era O the ongoing fourth observing run The present subject happens to be a chance coincidence of two unrelated glitches so in this case the search results are a bit of a mixed bunch too but will include a few other cases of a short duration glitch at higher frequencies coinciding with scattered light features at lower frequencies For classification purposes the central glitch would take precedence If you ask the tool for just one result you'll learn that the peak frequency where the noise was loudest above the background of the present subject was Hz at a signal to background noise ratio SNR of with a reported duration of seconds These numbers come straight from the "Omicron" software that detected the glitch in the first place in the data stream You'll also get a timeline "histogram" consisting of a single blue rectangle hours wide centered on the event time with some practice the time can be read off to within minutes 14T UTC when combined with the date shown for O subjects when you click the nfo button under the subject image The event date in turn can be used to glance at the Detector Summary Page for the day tab https gwosc org detector status day which is sometimes useful to check when a lockloss occurred or whether there was an unusual amount of seismic ground motion And some kinds of glitches are sufficiently unusual to have resulted in matching discussions in the observatory logbooks In the present case there isn't anything specific but the day shift operator's report LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep mentions general glitchiness impacting the sensitivity range which is echoed by the incoming evening shift operator in LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep The shift handover happened to happen at midnight UTC local time PST thus about an hour after the present subject had been recorded And of course you can always ask here in Talk about anything strange or unusual! After three years of upgrades the current glitch mix is rather different from what we had seen in the past and from what's documented in the Field Guide so you'll meet a lot of subjects that may be hard to recognize or that are genuinely new and None Of The Above We're still figuring out what's what and there's something new and unexpected coming up just about new every month That said I'm not sure how this present subject came about aside from the ancillary low frequency scattered light features The central glitch here is rare and unusual It isn't a whistle we haven't had any whistles at all during O so far It could have arisen from two closely spaced overlapping blips with partial cancellation between them It could perhaps have something to do with rung up violin modes in one of the test mass suspensions there's a mention of that in other logbook entries around this time but the peak frequency doesn't fit VMs would have to show up near Hz or multiples thereof https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3418449/ Remarks There seems to be some confusion tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep even within internal LIGO documents about which frequencies correspond to bounce modes and which to roll modes of the HAM somethingorother Triple Suspensions collectively abbreviated HXTS I'm going with LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep which puts the bounce modes around Hz and the roll modes around and Hz and which is in line with the Beam Splitter's triple suspension bounce mode near Hz roll mode near Hz and the quads bounce modes below Hz roll modes Hz tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk The primary resonances of the other four HXTS degrees of freedom longitudinal and transversal pendulum motion and angular motion in pitch and yaw are lower than Hz The HAM Large Triple Suspensions HLTS hosting the PR and SR mirrors have slightly higher resonances than the several types of small ones HSTS above rather than below Hz and near rather than Hz Thus I believe most of the glitches under consideration come from the HLTS whence my collection titles LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Oct had some nice mugshots of these suspects PR in its HLTS seen from the reflecting side looking back along the input arm from the beam splitter on the left with MC and MC in their HSTSs on the right ! PR MC MC in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg With a human for scale ! PR in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg And the rear side of SR in its HLTS looking from the detection end towards the beam splitter with SRM in its HSTS on the right hidden behind the output Faraday isolator in its suspension ! SR in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads SR3back jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads SR3back jpg Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab https www ligo caltech edu page image use policy About the coupling It is almost inevitable that the second harmonic will arise when a concave mirror oscillates vertically under a stationary centered beam spot the light path length will increase and decrease twice per cycle a classic example of upconversion caused by a nonlinearity the change in light path length being proportional to the square of the displacement of the optics and the alignment in pitch will also go off nominal twice per cycle It's less obvious that the fundamental frequency itself is also going to couple but the beam spot during normal operation will reside a little off center due to alignment requirements on other optics A pure roll mode motion rotation around the beam axis around the center of mass of the mirror should ideally not couple at all but in the real world it does primarily because the roll mode is a motion of the entire suspended payload top mass intermediate mass and mirror along with the connecting wires and blade springs so the center of the mirror will also move a little And imperfections in the highly reflective coating will move under the stationary not quite central beam spot too The HLTS actuators are driven by their control loops only at low frequencies where it matters for the L P Y degrees of freedom below about Hz Thus the bounce and roll modes are only passively damped Back in March during ER before O LLO engineers had mentioned this apropos of tracking down noise near Hz in DARM ultimately pinning it on the PR HSTS bounce mode at Hz LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep The damping of Livingston's HAM triple suspensions was revisited in June and July LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep Looking at the timeline distribution of the present glitches the tweaks made at the time seem to have been beneficial even though this campaign focused on the lower frequencies the bounce mode subjects become less common afterwards However the main source of ground motion in the anthropogenic Hz bands timber logging in the vicinity of LLO also went away by late August Attached to the last comment in that thread is a partial noise budget from early July the bounce mode contributions from all the triple suspensions are clearly visible around Hz for the roll modes we only see the resulting Hz peak in DARM ! LLO triple suspension contributions to the noise budget as of https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads M1damping ALL png 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads M1damping ALL png For the Gravity Spy workflows The SUS channels of the PR and SR suspensions might see the motion among the PEM channels accelerometers near HAM PR and HAM SR should see any jolts corresponding to the onsets of reverberations Perhaps we can use these to disambiguate which glitches come from PR and which from SR A very curious phenomenon shows up in a few subjects the bounce mode fundamental line and sometimes also the second harmonic splits symmetrically into two for a while as if it or its coupling into the strain channel were subjected to significant amplitude modulation at up to a few Hz ! This belongs to a new class of glitches that first showed up at Hanford on and soon earned their own glitch class proposal tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk so None Of The Above is the best choice while the proposal is being evaluated Power Line glitches are tied to the Hz mains frequency and they tend to look different We haven't had any from Hanford yet during the ongoing fourth observing run as far as I can tell but here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a power line are some examples from Livingston You'll meet quite a few None Of The Above subjects as you advance through the workflows many glitches won't fit into the available old classes After three years of upgrades the LIGO interferometers are now producing a glitch mix that's very different from anything we had seen before Several old classes no longer occur some still occur but look different and quite a lot of completely new stuff is coming up We're still in the middle of working out what's what and every month there's yet another novelty https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3416665/ which additional resources may I use to delve deep into this subject? E if I wish to use subject ID to pivot from these images to smth in order to understand what is happening https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3416650/ Welcome to Gravity Spy Talk PyroclasticFlow and thank you for contributing! Our Talk > Help > Resources tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk page links to a whole lot of material For example you may want to skim the article P Nguyen al Environmental Noise in Advanced LIGO Detectors tab https arxiv org pdf PDF arXiv astro ph IM Classical and Quantum Gravity Volume Number written and illustrated for a scientifically interested audience who is not yet familiar with the details of how environmental noise impacts the observatories including producing glitches and what steps are being taken to mitigate it This paper provides a broad general picture For specific subjects the first follow on question is usually whether it's a one of a kind thing or part of a larger population of similar glitches You can feed the Zooniverse subject number to the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search and ask for example for results from interferometers "ifo" H and L era O the ongoing fourth observing run The present subject happens to be a chance coincidence of two unrelated glitches so in this case the search results are a bit of a mixed bunch too but will include a few other cases of a short duration glitch at higher frequencies coinciding with scattered light features at lower frequencies For classification purposes the central glitch would take precedence If you ask the tool for just one result you'll learn that the peak frequency where the noise was loudest above the background of the present subject was Hz at a signal to background noise ratio SNR of with a reported duration of seconds These numbers come straight from the "Omicron" software that detected the glitch in the first place in the data stream You'll also get a timeline "histogram" consisting of a single blue rectangle hours wide centered on the event time with some practice the time can be read off to within minutes 14T UTC when combined with the date shown for O subjects when you click the nfo button under the subject image The event date in turn can be used to glance at the Detector Summary Page for the day tab https gwosc org detector status day which is sometimes useful to check when a lockloss occurred or whether there was an unusual amount of seismic ground motion And some kinds of glitches are sufficiently unusual to have resulted in matching discussions in the observatory logbooks In the present case there isn't anything specific but the day shift operator's report LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep mentions general glitchiness impacting the sensitivity range which is echoed by the incoming evening shift operator in LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep The shift handover happened to happen at midnight UTC local time PST thus about an hour after the present subject had been recorded And of course you can always ask here in Talk about anything strange or unusual! After three years of upgrades the current glitch mix is rather different from what we had seen in the past and from what's documented in the Field Guide so you'll meet a lot of subjects that may be hard to recognize or that are genuinely new and None Of The Above We're still figuring out what's what and there's something new and unexpected coming up just about new every month That said I'm not sure how this present subject came about aside from the ancillary low frequency scattered light features The central glitch here is rare and unusual It isn't a whistle we haven't had any whistles at all during O so far It could have arisen from two closely spaced overlapping blips with partial cancellation between them It could perhaps have something to do with rung up violin modes in one of the test mass suspensions there's a mention of that in other logbook entries around this time but the peak frequency doesn't fit VMs would have to show up near Hz or multiples thereof https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3416650/ Since our researchers have recently requested examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk of glitch classes that the Machine Learning as currently trained often mistakes for Scattered Light here's one such These glitches are quite rare true Scattered Light glitches outnumber them more than a hundredfold But they include visually striking specimens and they can be tentatively tied to some hardware that hasn't been discussed in Gravity Spy Talk before Proposed Name HXTS bounce and roll modes ID of proposer thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location d d 37da 42f a af ae png 180x tab showing the fourth frames Short description Long duration horizontal lines at and or and or Hz sometimes with additional frequencies present Characteristics All convincing examples I've seen so far come from Livingston although I know of no reason why they couldn't also occur at Hanford The bounce mode glitches would show up near Hz often with a prominent second harmonic near Hz The main roll mode resonance sits near Hz Bounce and roll modes can occur together with either dominating or separately SNRs vary wildly from less than to more than Bounce mode glitches were more common during the early months of O4a and some of them coincided with elevated ground motion in the Hz band visible on the Detector Status Summary Pages tab https gw openscience org detector status Roll mode glitches can occur as reverberations after marked jolts which can briefly excite a number of additional frequencies this morphology seems to have first occurred in September Most subjects have got rendered at Q Some from the aftermath of longer lasting reverberations have attracted lower Q renderings where they are poorly visible tab down to not visible at all tab Differential diagnosis The peak frequencies help to distinguish these from other kinds of jolts and reverberations Hanford's medium frequency ripples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk include a spectral line near Hz but their line spacing is different Hanford's Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk glitches are reported at or Hz higher than most of Livingston's bounce mode glitches In July and August and always on Wednesdays Livingston experienced some excess noise at multiples of Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3418449/ Remarks There seems to be some confusion tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep even within internal LIGO documents about which frequencies correspond to bounce modes and which to roll modes of the HAM somethingorother Triple Suspensions collectively abbreviated HXTS I'm going with LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep which puts the bounce modes around Hz and the roll modes around and Hz and which is in line with the Beam Splitter's triple suspension bounce mode near Hz roll mode near Hz and the quads bounce modes below Hz roll modes Hz tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk The primary resonances of the other four HXTS degrees of freedom longitudinal and transversal pendulum motion and angular motion in pitch and yaw are lower than Hz The HAM Large Triple Suspensions HLTS hosting the PR and SR mirrors have slightly higher resonances than the several types of small ones HSTS above rather than below Hz and near rather than Hz Thus I believe most of the glitches under consideration come from the HLTS whence my collection titles LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Oct had some nice mugshots of these suspects PR in its HLTS seen from the reflecting side looking back along the input arm from the beam splitter on the left with MC and MC in their HSTSs on the right ! PR MC MC in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg With a human for scale ! PR in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSC jpg And the rear side of SR in its HLTS looking from the detection end towards the beam splitter with SRM in its HSTS on the right hidden behind the output Faraday isolator in its suspension ! SR in situ from LLO https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads SR3back jpg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads SR3back jpg Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab https www ligo caltech edu page image use policy About the coupling It is almost inevitable that the second harmonic will arise when a concave mirror oscillates vertically under a stationary centered beam spot the light path length will increase and decrease twice per cycle a classic example of upconversion caused by a nonlinearity the change in light path length being proportional to the square of the displacement of the optics and the alignment in pitch will also go off nominal twice per cycle It's less obvious that the fundamental frequency itself is also going to couple but the beam spot during normal operation will reside a little off center due to alignment requirements on other optics A pure roll mode motion rotation around the beam axis around the center of mass of the mirror should ideally not couple at all but in the real world it does primarily because the roll mode is a motion of the entire suspended payload top mass intermediate mass and mirror along with the connecting wires and blade springs so the center of the mirror will also move a little And imperfections in the highly reflective coating will move under the stationary not quite central beam spot too The HLTS actuators are driven by their control loops only at low frequencies where it matters for the L P Y degrees of freedom below about Hz Thus the bounce and roll modes are only passively damped Back in March during ER before O LLO engineers had mentioned this apropos of tracking down noise near Hz in DARM ultimately pinning it on the PR HSTS bounce mode at Hz LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep The damping of Livingston's HAM triple suspensions was revisited in June and July LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep Looking at the timeline distribution of the present glitches the tweaks made at the time seem to have been beneficial even though this campaign focused on the lower frequencies the bounce mode subjects become less common afterwards However the main source of ground motion in the anthropogenic Hz bands timber logging in the vicinity of LLO also went away by late August Attached to the last comment in that thread is a partial noise budget from early July the bounce mode contributions from all the triple suspensions are clearly visible around Hz for the roll modes we only see the resulting Hz peak in DARM ! LLO triple suspension contributions to the noise budget as of https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads M1damping ALL png 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads M1damping ALL png For the Gravity Spy workflows The SUS channels of the PR and SR suspensions might see the motion among the PEM channels accelerometers near HAM PR and HAM SR should see any jolts corresponding to the onsets of reverberations Perhaps we can use these to disambiguate which glitches come from PR and which from SR A very curious phenomenon shows up in a few subjects the bounce mode fundamental line and sometimes also the second harmonic splits symmetrically into two for a while as if it or its coupling into the strain channel were subjected to significant amplitude modulation at up to a few Hz ! image 2318945e ea a 3 c png https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3418449/ Progress What's really going on near Hz There's no such a thing as a single " Hz line" class A number of different causes have been at work here and several phenomena showing up near this frequency are intertwined with one or more other frequencies A determined push of cascaded deeper than usual similarity searches has finally dredged up sufficiently many subjects to justify a glitch class proposal Bounce and roll modes of the HAM triple suspensions tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk but only if we treat the bounce mode near Hz and its second harmonic Hz and the roll mode near Hz together they can occur together or separately and I'm confident that their causes and coupling mechanisms are closely related These do preferentially attract high Q renderings and many of them have been mis labeled as Scattered Light So this is one lot that may be worth feeding to the ML as training sets My four relevant collections are linked from the proposal Recapitulating the other known contributors near Hz The LLO "Wednesday glitches" always at the same hour of LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep at Hz from July August seem to have produced only six eight subjects tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l a dot hz wednesday glitches if we ignore duplicate uploads of the same glitch in two cases Three of these have been labeled Scattered Light one Low Frequency Lines and four No Glitch From Hanford we have the subset of MF ripples combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk where the Hz line happens to dominate over those near and Hz But that subset isn't a glitch class in its own right and shouldn't be used to train the ML Rather the existing training set H ER O4a MF ripple comb Hz tab https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set h er a mf ripple comb hz should be used if this is to be turned into an official glitch class And also from Hanford the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk with O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er a hz ground motion coupling and O4b tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er b hz ground motion coupling collections Still growing I have dozens more enqueued to be taken through further sim searches These have attracted renderings at all four Q values and can't be classified by their images alone they will have to await a future ML implementation which is 81Hz Q 6 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3419848/ Flock or is it a shoal? lighthouse koi plus other noise https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3419850/ Predictions are hard especially when they concern the future The current plan tab https observing docs ligo org plan is for O4b to continue into early June followed by another round of significant upgrades followed by O when everything is ready tentatively pencilled in for about three years from now but schedules have a way of slipping The upgrades will include new heavier test masses and a new bigger beam splitter in the middle along with suitably strengthened suspensions for these and a number of other things Some auxiliary hardware is already being assembled and tested for a glimpse see LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep One major technological advance still needs to become production ready novel highly reflective coatings for the test masses mirrors made from a new combination of materials in order to reduce the thermal motion of the atoms in the coatings at a given temperature https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3419832/ Nothing of note was recorded at Livingston As earthquakes go it wasn't a strong one magnitude on the verge of being noticeable at all to someone in a quiet room at the epicentre But since it was close to Hanford its waves arrived all at once not dispersed over many minutes and they showed up in the Hz bands the sharp very tall spikes at UTC in the ground motion plots in the summary page for tab https gwosc org detector status day environment ground motion rather than in the Hz bands where stronger distant earthquakes would register https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3419835/ Just the sweet screeching sound of invisible violins tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep violin !      wow thank you so much ZngabitanT for a such detailed answer! It definitely endorses me to dive into gravity spy data again and again knowing my questions are going to be addressed in a very comprehensive and friendly manner I will definitely try to get familiar with similarity search tool so far I am trying to establish some kind of a pipeline of subsequent actions which one should do in general to investigate different glitches I've just started to understand time frequency resolution tradeoffs which on its own is kind of hard to wrap one's head around now there are additional tools At least it seems to me there are so many different sources to consider but I've got a feeling something settles in my head at last https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3416650/ Thank you sounds like a plan! Do take it easy though Rome LIGO wasn't built in a day and there's no substitute for experience acquired over many weeks months and years Keep going and experience will settle on your shoulders like snow on a tree My personal subject studying routine is somewhat complicated but it has evolved over more then five years and is underpinned by having looked at more than a hundred thousand glitches and by keeping long lists of subject numbers and annotations in offline files Let me recommend one additional source of information It's worth keeping a corner of an eye on what other people both veterans and new volunteers are posting in our Talk boards tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk There are some gems to be found also among comments from past years so when you're just finishing classifying something interesting looking you can click Done Talk instead of Done to see the subject's Talk page and any prior discussions linked from it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3416650/ Hi Since at least July to date there are several mentions in Talk of a pending DYCWMI tool bugfix to have it work with ER and O subjects I tried the tool today and it still returns a No data available in table https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu collection info collection info ?username coralbell collection display name cairn l o Being already through O4b the tool is much needed for volunteer glitch investigations by offering collection metadata at a glance to observe ranges group characteristics and more As external text editing files are to be used to investigate glitches in the absence of the DYCWMI tool a manual copy paste is required for collections in painstaking manual work subject by subject for what the tool would automatically provide Even further histograms are important visualization tools to determine how the population distribution of collections behaves In the absence of an automated collection histogram it is very challenging to try to create an external distribution chart because with event time metadata null in sim search until O data is publicly released the event date needs to be manually extracted from each spectrogram through the Info button be manually added to each subject metadata row in that external file then processed and finetuned Repeat this many times till an investigation turns satisfactory enough The DYCWMI tool is very useful to the community at large and is vital to round up information and decisions as investigative collections evolve into final curated sets with all information ready for the researchers to consider I would like to hear about the status of the tool bugfix and when it would be expected to be operational with ER and O collections Thank you for your attention and all efforts done by the teams to fix bugs all along Sincerely Carmen https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3421335/
