between about and 72Hz and the tips between about and 400Hz with a frequency of about 125s between peaks https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422780/ A pair of koi fish with the heads centered at about and 0s and a blip centered at about 8s https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422784/ Whistle https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/157809/ Lfb https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423032/ Background noise much more vibrant in this one! Something weird happened here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Yes! We're living on a restless planet Even aside from earthquakes strong enough to be felt the ground beneath our feet is always in motion at speeds of up to about a micrometer per second caused by a mix of weak distant earthquakes wind driven ocean wave activity human activity plus gusts of wind leaning on building walls which then lean on the pillars which support them which then causes the floor under the pillars to tilt a little LIGO's vacuum chambers and the beam tubes connecting them along with anything attached to the walls of the vacuum vessels follow these ground motions Inside four of the large vacuum chambers at each site there are the test masses in their four stage "quad" pendulum suspensions mounted on a three stage internal seismic isolation structure mounted in turn on a hydraulic external pre isolation For some pictures of the hardware see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk So the test masses move a whole lot less than everything around them Between the polished mirror coated front surfaces of the test masses in each arm the main laser beams are circulating Tiny imperfections of the coatings cause a tiny fraction of the laser light to be scattered out of the beams in arbitrary directions Most of the stray light hits one of many baffles and is absorbed A tiny fraction of the stray light however may hit something reflective attached to the walls which are moving relative to the test masses A tiny fraction of the reflected light may hit the nearest test mass again and get scattered back to interfere with the main beam This fraction is what ultimately shows up as glitches If the stray light path length was constant it wouldn't be a problem the backscattered light may be out of phase with the main beam but that's no different from one test mass being a tiny wee little bit in the wrong place which would be automatically corrected But since the reflecting item would be moving relative to the test mass the stray light path length will also change and the phase relationship between the backscattered light and the main beam will change If the stray light path length changes by say s which is approximately laser wavelengths per second we'll get visible noise at about Hz Moreover multiple reflections can cause the stray light path to be traversed multiple times and then we'll also get visible noise at higher frequencies stacks of parallel arches The top of an arch always corresponds to the moment when the reflecting item was moving fastest in one direction or the other relative to the test mass At moments when the motion stops and turns around the arches descend off the bottom of our images The hunt for the causes involves careful analysis of videos of the near infrared light and actively shaking the beam tubes and measuring the effects both with accelerometers mounted on the beam tubes and chambers and in the light that ultimately reaches the detection photodiodes One recent logbook entry among many is LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep continuing an investigation started in March in LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep Two infrared still photos attached to comments on the latter logbook entry LIGO Livingston's X end test mass in its suspension center seen from rear left to its right is the suspended reaction mass with circular electrostatic actuator traces plated on it the angular structure on the left is the Arm Cavity Baffle All of the illumination captured here by the camera comes from stray laser light ! LLO ETMX quad https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg Those gold plated electrostatic traces used to be the reflecting item responsible for the classic multi arch Scattered Light glitches during past observing runs This has been addressed since January by more carefully steering the suspensions to keep the distance between each test mass and the reaction mass behind it very nearly constant Any remaining glitches from this path would now occur below Hz where we won't see them in our subject images Looking a little further to the left with the test mass out of view beyond the right edge we now have the Arm Cavity Baffle on the right the cryopump baffle with two glints on its right edge left of center and a on the left a rather bright double glint off a spool piece where there's a large gate valve in the X arm beam tube The corner station would be km further away at rear left ! LLO glints near the end of the X arm https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab https www ligo caltech edu page image use policy The cryopump baffle is unlikely to be "it" they used to vibrate quite a lot in the presence of elevated ground motion levels and they were responsible for a lot of glitches during O but steps have since been taken to prevent them from vibrating The spool piece might be "it" but this has neither been proven nor ruled out yet The changes in the light path length implied by the frequencies of our arches seem a bit too large for it the spool piece shouldn't be able to move that much Hope this helps a little! By the way note that we don't see the main beam in these images There are more than kW of laser light circulating along earch arm between the reflecting surfaces of the input and end test masses but everything is happening inside a hard vacuum Thus there are next to no air molecules anywhere between the test masses that would scatter some light out of the beam towards the camera as they would if the beam was travelling in air https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ This is a rather common form that Scattered Light glitches from Hanford have been taking during the ongoing fourth observing run No well formed arches just wavy more or less parallel bits and fragments at frequencies mostly between and Hz sometimes with additional pieces between and Hz The band between and Hz tends to appear dark in most of our images It is blanketed by loud stationary noise which gets suppressed before our spectrogram images are created Only the loudest glitches manage to exceed the background noise in this band and show up there as well https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Very cool! So a lot of parts reflect just not into the recieving sensor? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Yes a lot of things inside the vacuum vessels are shiny and reflective One can't simply paint everything flat black paints don't go well with vacuum Paint molecules would evaporate drift around and settle somewhere else even on the test masses where we absolutely don't want them The baffles get special coatings of non smooth light absorbing materials and even then their edges can still reflect some light But the total area of the large vacuum chambers and long beam tubes is just too much to treat it all in this way That said the mirrors which are meant to reflect light in the intended directions are of exceedingly high quality and almost all of the light does go where it is meant to go The coatings on the end test masses reflect more than of the laser light! And the few parts per million that get through these coatings aren't wasted They are captured by additional optics behind the test masses and are used to measure the circulating light power and the beam position and angle https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Very cool! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Baby koi school https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423913/ School of melted blips https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423915/ Scattered light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423919/ School koi plus ? looking for Cairn O L through cascading sim searches large and small Few possibly fitting subjects showed up as the pattern goes but the Cairn L O tab https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections coralbell cairn l o collection grew up a bit more Notes Certain glitch behavioural traits still remain unknown to us due to the unfeasibility to work with O raw data on the volunteer side in order to see what happens in a wider timespan of The unavailability so far of the DYCWMI tool to work with ER and O collections hinders what I can observe in a collection as a whole such as metadata ranges trend population distribution interesting timeline gaps and other valuable insights Among those subjects that I kept collecting several ones happen to be already in ZngabitanT collections L ER O4a Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a cairn and L ER O4b Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b cairn This might eventually give us a lower possible number of overall collected subjects for a potential training set Nonetheless I persist as I would truly like to get enough good representative subjects to take Cairn a step forward All collection subjects so far are rendered with Q value except subject https www zooniverse org with Q value The initial duration upper boundary of about seems now short to me As duration goes up to in gold set subject https www zooniverse org I collected subjects up to about to get a broader view but they might turn out to be borderline It keeps hinting at a small underlying population in L O so far Observations Gold subject https www zooniverse org like some others differs at Q value in that the alignment of the right end of the upper stacking lines in frame recedes in a slant downwards to the right side instead of filling up the frame from side to side Frame follows suit remaining asymmetrical The other population of glitches filling up frame from side to side in general has a well balanced right left view of the mound sides in frame as in mirror symmetry though not in perfect reflection A couple of such starboard morphologies as I nicknamed them showed up in searches fitting the other requirements so I included them in my L O collection These happen both in O4a and O4b sometimes in reverse port formation receding in a slant downwards to the left side of the spectrogram towards the "bow These morphologies happen to be also present in both collections by ZngabitanT L ER O4a Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a cairn and L ER O4b Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b cairn At this point I am unsure as to what is expected from Cairn O in this regard how asymmetrical the shape can be As a gold subject shows this pattern I feel that the description mound and alike are not exact being a certain mirror symmetry expected Real cairns range from perfectly symmetrical structures to crumbled or dispersed collections of rocks so perhaps a mound does not describe all the asymmetrical variations appearing in Q value and sometimes Q value Ongoing Question The following is a question I still have from the beginning and makes it more difficult for me to form a clearer concept about the Cairn morphology at Q and at times Q Do we need at least two prominent lines to form a Cairn shape? For example a one line subject is gold subject https www zooniverse org and subject https www zooniverse org in my collection In my opinion a cairn should need several prominent elements piled up not just a slightly curved single line Hence do we consider the very faint lines as defining elements? While metadata values may fit what exactly should we be looking for in this regard? Thank you Addenda the first two bullets under Observations can also be taken as the glitch extending in frame along the time axis https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/729/3399349/ Wheatgrass https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424324/ ? 17Hz Q Scattered light variant? One possibility I've been mulling over and which may turn out to be wrong is that Cairns might be another part of the same population as Vibration Eruptions tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 1009409?comment where in the latter case the reflecting item the cryopump baffles used to be the prime suspect would be vibrating with larger amplitude thus upconverting the noise to higher frequencies at the culmination and as a byproduct also raising the decay phase which lasts a few seconds to frequencies above Hz where it doesn't get completely drowned out by the stationary background noise Like Cairns Vibration Eruptions attract renderings at a variety of Q values and they are roughly equally rare In this light it is interesting that you've picked up three in between subjects that I would be inclined to file under Vibration Eruption ! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425678/ That depends We've had a few genuine Power Line glitches from Livingston during O so far which tend to look like these with a characteristic pair of "eyes" and with varying amounts of spillover to other frequencies ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 518fc c aa 9b 996198c f png tab ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 8 b 00ac b 132 f png tab ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 98a cbf 36d 4 d 9b dbf png tab They are caused by some Hz alternating current circuit switching on and off or off and on faster than the line subtraction filtering can follow The ever present Hz noise will be momentarily overcompensated then undercompensated then overcompensated again The stationary Hz noise mostly couples through magnetic fields There's a number of voltage monitors current monitors and magnetometers deployed and for each of them the correlation to the differential arm length measurements is known and periodically re measured and used to calibrate the subtraction But any filtering or subtraction confined to a very narrow frequency band necessarily takes time to react to changing conditions And while the subtraction is good overall or else the Hz peak in the noise spectrum would be much higher! it isn't perfect the actual coupling sites aren't quite where the magnetometers are You might enjoy skimming the paper P Nguyen al Environmental Noise in Advanced LIGO Detectors tab https arxiv org pdf PDF arXiv astro ph IM Classical and Quantum Gravity Volume Number But there are also other kinds of glitches at adjacent frequencies unrelated to the electricity mains and not covered by the Hz mitigation E The suspensions of some auxiliary optics have a "bounce mode" resonance near Hz which can show up tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk at multiples thereof including Hz ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location a 96b 41ef c png tab Between and Livingston experienced a series of very varied glitches tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3314162?comment that seriously impacted the sensitivity mostly with peak frequencies of Hz or multiples thereof Some of these could look deceptively like Hz "line" noise ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 8caa 41d bc a png tab After a lot of noise hunting by the engineers the cause for these along a complicated coupling path turned out tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep to be a single signal cable somewhere in the squeezer subsystem that was plugged tab https en wikipedia org wiki D subminiature into an electronics chassis but not properly fastened with both screws tightened https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Footnote Narrowband noise spectral lines are dealt with in different ways on different time scales The published data on GWOSC have been carefully cleaned offline over the course of months after the end of each observing run The near realtime data on which the plots on the status summary pages are based have undergone near realtime cleaning which since it needs to be fast and has to rely on estimates extrapolations of slowly changing parameters can't be quite as good The Omicron software looks for glitches in a raw data stream that hasn't yet been line cleaned Gravity Spy subject images are created from the same raw data after a preprocessing "whitening" step which somewhat imperfectly subdues any noise which looks stationary on timescales of around one minute So what we see in our subject images is based on a cruder form of line noise suppression than the data that are later uploaded to GWOSC https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Panoptes authentication uses a secure cookie That been true since the Panoptes API launched in Session cookies are used for some other bits of user personalisation like remembering whether you prefer a light or dark theme User preferences aren dated so I can see which workflow you last worked on but I don know if that was last week or last year That leads to bugs most notably a project team sends out an email with a link to their classify page previous volunteers follow the link and their preferences load a completed workflow This in turn leads to excess classifications on subjects that have already been completed https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ Ok thank you for the clarification! We'll see how this plays out then https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ One improvement that has been made in the new code is that you can link directly to specific workflows by workflow ID That a lot more reliable than trying to guess from user preferences eg https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy classify workflow 1610 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ At some point they will be once the detector engineers and the machine learning experts have reached a consensus about how best to address the needs At the present time it isn't even clear yet how best to carve up the glitches lately caused by scattered light into classes that are on the one hand amenable to classifying by their images limited to frequencies above Hz and to seconds' worth on the time axis and on the other hand make sense from an engineering perspective Considering the impact on clean observing time glitches which remain confined below Hz do less harm than glitches showing up at higher frequencies From this angle it might make sense to maintain the distinction between Scattered Light with arches visible above Hz and Low Frequency Burst without such even though the same causes are at work From a cause hunting angle lumping them together looks more attractive From a mitigation angle if something can be done to push the arches below Hz it would already be considered good progress and once again separate classes would help to measure the benefits And from an ML angle the current neural network is struggling to make sense of edge cases like tab or tab but also with obvious rows of arches la Livingston O ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 300x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location fd b f 4 d 84a fc png tab Upgrading and retraining the ML would help along with selecting new sets of example illustrations and of gold standard subjects along the way but would make it hard to compare future ML and volunteer classifications to existing ML and volunteer classifications of older subjects unless all the older subjects are also reprocessed and the Detector Characterization team expends extra time to familiarize themselves with the revised results So there is no easy win We've learned many lessons over the years and there are certainly things we'd do differently if we were to start over from scratch including better ways to adapt to unforeseen changes in the glitch mix For the moment we'll have to live within the limitations of the existing ML design use our human eyes and brains trained by millions of years of evolution to recognize ripe fruit and tiger stripes behind the foliage build representative collections and keep working on gradually improving the whole affair And your input is much appreciated! Indeed this was a completely new kind of glitch tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk first noted from LIGO Hanford on The cause remains unkown In late April another series of similar looking glitches happened again at Hanford during a couple of days And then from until we got a few hundred somewhat similar glitches from Livingston two of which are among your similarity search results In that case the cause is known it turned out tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep to be a single signal cable somewhere in the squeezer subsystem that was plugged tab https en wikipedia org wiki D subminiature into an electronics chassis but not properly fastened with both screws tightened Glitches from all three of these episodes have attracted a mix of low Q and high Q renderings so they differ widely in appearance If you want to see for yourself how a Blip changes in appearance under different rendering choices let's take one from O where the precise event timestamps and raw data have been published by now Head to the glitch plotter tab https gwo glitch plotter streamlit app ask it to load say seconds of data from H around timestamp 13T UTC GPS as it will compute for you and then scroll down both the navigation pane on the left and the panel with the plots on the right and pick different Q values with the slider and apply them The corresponding Gravity Spy subject is tab The same can be done with a published Binary Black Hole BBH chirp from O say GW tab https gwosc org eventapi html GWTC confident GW v which corresponds to subjects tab and tab Use 09T has the event time Enjoy! Per the current version of the LIGO Data Management Plan tab https dcc ligo org LIGO M public we'll need to wait until late August before we'll be able to access the raw data corresponding to subjects from the first half O4a of O and play with them in the same way https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426474/ Yes the top of one arch just barely peeping over the bottom edge and then the top of a lesser parallel arch just above the dark Hz stationary noise band https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426516/ Because each of these baby Koi glitches is a very close overlapping double two humps at the top end and often a few dark holes down the middle where the two short duration things partially cancel https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426519/ Not too fuzzy just Scattered Light rendered at Q in between wheatgrass and scattering comb shapes https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ It hard working out which is which! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Thank you I find it very difficult to make out Easily missed! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426516/ Be assured that you're miles ahead of the ML in this regard https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Thank you! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ I ve updated the GitHub PR to explain how a SameSite cookie protects against accidentally loading the wrong workflow when following a link from an email or external site https github com zooniverse front end monorepo pull discussion r https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ As a matter of interest maybe to others like myself what on earth is ConvNN? I have seen it when doing sim searches and should have asked this years ago It is something I doubt I will ever need to use but I am interested where it fits in to the whole AI ML scheme of things Please is there a VERY basic explanation? Thank you No hurry! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Sorry to hear it I have passed the message on to the person who developed the promotion system and hope to have a fix soon https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ When I check though it says you are in level Could you reload the site and see what levels are unlocked? Or is it promotion to level that's not working? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ Promotion to level is not working https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ A Convolutional Neural Network tab https en wikipedia org wiki Convolutional neural network ConvNN for short sometimes CNN for even shorter is a computer program which aims to simulate a network of nerve cells wired together in ways somewhat similar to those in our retinas and brain which underlie our sense of vision Among the different approaches to Machine Learning this is one particularly suited to image processing and therefore the one chosen for the Gravity Spy ML The simulated cells are arranged in layers The given image is divided into arrays of overlapping little squares The image data in each square are fed into one of the cells in the first layer Each of these input cells reacts to left right or up down or diagonal gradients brightness variations in its input square this is the "convolutional" part The outputs of the first layer cells in all sorts of combinations are processed further by the next layers Each successive layer is able to detect more complicated combinations of image traits straight or curved edges small or large uniform regions arches parallel streaks fuzziness Nessie coils After some four or five or six intermediate layers the final output layer consists of one cell for each glitch class or whatever one is trying to classify The one that "shouts most loudly" determines the label that will be attached to the image and how loudly it "shouts" compared to the others provides a confidence estimate During training the connections among the layers are strengthened or weakened at random until the outputs delivered on the training images agree reasonably well with the intended classifications This too aims to imitate how we understand learning to happen in real brains Hope this is suitably basic! This is a Rarely Asked Question so it's not addressed in the FAQ page https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ bonjour je n'ai pas bien compris quoi sert ce que nous faisons les observations ont apparemment j classifi es alors quoi sert de les classifi es de nouveau? ou est ce de l'entrainement pour traiter ensuite des observations non classifi es? merci de votre ponse https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428114/ Bienvenu au Zooniverse et Gravity Spy! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Among the various O "NotNoGlitch" subjects a few hundred mostly from Hanford O4b stand out They have peak frequencies near or near Hz and are readily tied to logbook entries about rung up violin modes The Machine Learning has been calling them No Glitch and indeed there's nothing much to see yet Omicron had triggered on them as excess noise with SNRs above or else they wouldn't exist as Gravity Spy subjects But it turns out that they don't actually represent glitches in the strain channel They represent elevated stationary noise levels in DARM and strain varying only gradually on time scales of minutes to hours They really originate as glitches in the glitch detection itself Thus I'm documenting them here as a distinct subclass of Violin Mode Harmonics Proposed Name LIGO O Invisible Violins ID of proposer ZngabitanT Date of proposal Reference subjects for Classifier and Field Guide S holotype linked above metadata tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu collection info collection info ?username zngabitant collection display name h er b invisible violins L ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu collection info collection info ?username zngabitant collection display name l er b invisible violins by ZngabitanT Collaborators dianasironi mitchnanny moderators researchers Remarks In fact not only is there an unusual excess of overlapping pairs of subjects these pairs also straddle full second boundaries at one minute intervals The examples from all come just before or just after a GPS second that fell seconds after a multiple of Those from all happened seconds after a multiple of On the other hand the seconds periodicity tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk of the Pizzicato glitches from O has disappeared completely Example pairs more will keep turning up from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab and from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab What must have been happening here is that Omicron in the presence of a rung up violin mode or other loud stationary narrowband noise tends to trigger near the end of its current seconds chunk of data and then again near the beginning of the next seconds chunk Sometimes only one member of such a pair of triggers will exceed the SNR > threshold for creating a Gravity Spy subject Sometimes both would remain too faint to show up here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ So what to do about these triggers? Are they useful? Are they necessary? Could we do without them? The observatory operators and the data quality team on their weekly shifts don't need them rung up violin modes are reported in other more direct ways They do add some spice to the Gravity Spy volunteer experience One more sort of thing that requires taking a closer look and extracting the peak frequency using the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search and a satisfyingly successful trip to the LIGO logbooks for corroboration But of course our personal enlightenment isn't the primary objective of the glitch detection software It is likely that they could be avoided by padding the minute long data chunks on which Omicron operates with shoulders of at least seconds on both sides my experience whilst working with the glitch plotter tab https gwo glitch plotter streamlit app has been that I needed this much padding in order for the whitening to work satisfactorily and to avoid artefacts near the beginning and end of data chunks But this would increase the latency in the time critical path for vetoing candidate events that are accompanied by glitches in safe auxiliary channels So it may be better to keep things as they are and live with these "glitches" It's worth noting that the Virgo team had encountered a very similar issue at the beginning of O tab https logbook virgo gw eu virgo ?r and tuned the padding and overlap duration for their Omicron installation in April and again in June tab https logbook virgo gw eu virgo ?r And we had seen similar evenly spaced pairs of overlapping "NotNoGlitch" subjects from Virgo O https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ The images fed to the GravitySpy ML ConvNN day in day out while the observatories are Observing are the same that then get uploaded to Zooniverse as subjects for us to inspect except that the ML gets to "view" all four frames at once side by side and without the title texts colourmap axis tick marks and labels only the four spectrogram images themselves For re training purposes it would be fed a set of around a hundred such images carefully selected and believed to be representative of a single new glitch class In reality it's somewhat more complicated The set is split up randomly into a larger part used for the training phase and a smaller part for testing validation Then the current training subset is run through the neural network adjusting the cell connections in the process and the outcome is evaluated on the current test subset while keeping the connections fixed And then this is repeated with a new random splitting of the given subject set many times until the results no longer improve in further iterations The sort of language oriented AI that has been getting headlines in the last year and a half ChatGPT and friends works completely differently though The only commonalities are that they also run on computers and also need to be trained But they require vastly larger amounts of training data and existing Large Language Models have been trained on data of sometimes extremely dubious quality not to mention copyright infringements on a global scale https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ No doubt people will want to know about ChatGPT I have never used it but have actually heard about it Thank you for your as I see it I began a collection on these events Thank you https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Pretty catch! The title subject is a rare Q rendering of a flock as is The remainder of the sim search results is something of a mixed bunch Since the choice of Q value has such a large effect on the general texture of the resulting subject images the Similarity Search tool tends to be more sensitive to the Q value than to the glitch class And since flocks at Q are rare it returns an eclectic mix of other things instead Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Whether you're browsing recent pages or viewing the results of a logbook search is specific to your current browser session and can't be exported through a URL The link you see in the URL field of your browser when you're looking at the search results ends up pointing at the logbook start page for everyone else No loss in the present case since flocks aren't momentous enough as glitches go to earn specific logbook mentions Only individual logbook entries and comments on them can be linked to directly Their URLs can be captured for pasting by using the browser's "Copy link" function on the "Link" button in the entry heading https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Thank you for the feedback and information ZngabitanT An eclectic mix indeed as sim search sees it I took a look at the array of subjects tagged with "flock" there is a wide variety of glitches making up a flock seems pretty special > Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Yes I recalled something about this from previous logbook searches seeing that my draft post returned the Home page after having pasted the URL on top of the search results even though that search URL contained the corresponding "page 1" and "page 2" appended yet switched to the Home page when pasted into the address bar Many thanks! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/102358/ The glitches visible in the strain channel are classic multi arch Scattered Light the kind that was still common during most of the third observing run before it got fixed in January The auxiliary channel which monitors the light circulating in the X arm represented by the few parts per million of it which make it through the mirror coatings on the end test mass and then get captured by the optics of the transmission monitoring system didn't witness it on this occasion The present S is a counterpart to S https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429011/ Nice catch! This and similar subjects mostly from Hanford with brief sometimes repeating noise near and or around Hz are None Of The Above Sometimes we call them "Pirate Ships" by a superficial analogy with the old Virgo O glitch class of that name At Hanford they are caused by beam jitter they show up when the laser beam already wobbles sideways a little at the point where it enters the first vacuum chamber The subset near Hz got almost completely fixed in October the others still occur occasionally They are relatively rare They may yet earn a formal glitch class proposal once we've collected enough examples https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429184/ Another kind of None Of The Above These require a glance at the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search to read out the peak frequency Hz identifies the present subject as an example of this proposed glitch class tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches from the squeezer subsystem had been present between mid November and mid January when the first half O4a of the fourth observing run ended https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429187/ To clarify this is primarily a gold standard example of Repeating Blips intended to familiarize volunteers in the level workflow with cases where groups of individual glitchlets need to be treated as a whole and where it is essential to look at the fourth frame and take in the whole picture And I agree on the central constituent blip being slightly mis shapen because it is coincidentally blended with a bit of unrelated lower frequency noise In some cases ancient subjects that had already been uploaded once before the Gravity Spy tools existed to serve as gold standard examples were uploaded a second time later as ordinary subjects with new subject numbers and were then also added to the Similarity Search tool's database Thus Sim Search won't find the present subject under its original number but a search for the character subject id uniqueid IdrpGAG37s will succeed and will find the copy with subject number Note that the image was reprocessed for this purpose In the newer copy the image title mentions the first observing run O explicitly subject for further correlation to be honest I am not even sure with what can I correlate besides logbook and detector status page Anyway would be happy to know if it is normal to have some subject present on zooniverse website and missing somewhere else as well as get some tips on how to treat such examples https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Apologies for the invoncenience! Last year there were occasional hiccups with the subject upload process which resulted in repeated upload attempts and thus in accidental duplications and it has not been feasible to clean up completely afterwards The present glitch is one of that happened between and at Hanford cause unknown and not related to locklosses but nearly each of them was uploaded to Zooniverse five times under five different subject numbers without making it into the Gravity Spy tools before finally being successfully uploaded a sixth time The good and usable subjects from those days have numbers 9636xxxx the earlier 9287xxxx through 9343xxxx should be considered as extraneous duplicates If we were to remove them from Zooniverse now we would also orphan the associated Talk threads and produce inconsistencies in any collections containing them The usable version of the present subject is tab As to how to deal with the duplicates I would frown at them flag them as such by adding them to suitable marker collections and move on to the next subject There's also a small handful of subjects showing other kinds of glitches of which two or more copies exist in the Similarity Seach database and these can produce a different nondescript error when one asks for fewer results than the number of copies There used to be many more during O many subjects had been ingested four or five times and there was one that had got uploaded more than a thousand times those had been cleared out at one point leaving only one representative subject of each glitch Clearing out the few that exist at the present time would require a disproportionate amount of manual effort so we've left them alone https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ oki thanks for clarification! Recently I started getting glitches from this sequence one after another but was unable to find any info in Talk Btw how did you manage to find usable version of the subject in question? Definitely not by brute forcing subject IDs matching right? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Yes well observed you'll see this in a number of ancient subjects If I am not mistaken the reason is that back then well before my time the normalized noise energy was fed into the colormap as is whereas more recent subjects use the logarithm of the normalized energy which will show some finer glitch details as well as the random background more clearly Noise levels within a single subject image can vary by five orders of magnitude even after the removal of stationary noise "whitening" during preprocessing https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429884/ One of our veteran volunteers who is currently taking a break from Zooniverse had collected almost all of these two hundred something Hz glitch subjects as they come up whilst classifying Once our systematic similarity searches across the good ones found no further examples it was a matter of looking at each of the good ones in turn find its exact copies in the twenty odd collection pages where twelve subject per page are displayed write down the relationships in an offline file and remove the copies from the bulk collection so this eyeball search became easier with each glitch that we had dealt with A few duplicates had been missed and only showed up later and these could be tied in by eyeballing the collection of good representatives which fits on pages https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Can someone shed some light on what to classify this one please? What's less cool from a LIGO engineer's point of view is that this has been the most common type of glitch at Livingston since the beginning of the fourth observing run in May and it is still not clear how exactly these glitches arise We no longer get the sort of multi arch Scattered Light that was common in past years and that's illustrated in the Field Guide that sort was root caused in late tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and cleverly fixed in January before the end of O But we do still get stacks of Scattered Light arches shifted to somewhat lower frequencies as in this present example Most of the action is now below the Hz bottom edge of our images where it does little harm but one strong arch rises above the bottom edge to culminate near Hz and a fainter parallel arch reaches up to about Hz The two arches are separated by a darker band covering Hz punctuated by three evenly spaced streaks tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk that's a region where there's a lot of always present stationary background noise which gets suppressed before our images are created So it's a new variant of lower frequency Scattered Light but it's unclear where the scattering happens at the corner station or near one of the two test masses at the ends of the arms and it's unclear what the reflecting item is that's moving relative to the test masses https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Huh so if I understand it correctly something is moving which causes the laser to move slightly thus registering as a "quake" I don't know the appropiate terminolgy sorry and you don't yet know what exactly is moving? Something weird happened here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Yes! We're living on a restless planet Even aside from earthquakes strong enough to be felt the ground beneath our feet is always in motion at speeds of up to about a micrometer per second caused by a mix of weak distant earthquakes wind driven ocean wave activity human activity plus gusts of wind leaning on building walls which then lean on the pillars which support them which then causes the floor under the pillars to tilt a little LIGO's vacuum chambers and the beam tubes connecting them along with anything attached to the walls of the vacuum vessels follow these ground motions Inside four of the large vacuum chambers at each site there are the test masses in their four stage "quad" pendulum suspensions mounted on a three stage internal seismic isolation structure mounted in turn on a hydraulic external pre isolation For some pictures of the hardware see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk So the test masses move a whole lot less than everything around them Between the polished mirror coated front surfaces of the test masses in each arm the main laser beams are circulating Tiny imperfections of the coatings cause a tiny fraction of the laser light to be scattered out of the beams in arbitrary directions Most of the stray light hits one of many baffles and is absorbed A tiny fraction of the stray light however may hit something reflective attached to the walls which are moving relative to the test masses A tiny fraction of the reflected light may hit the nearest test mass again and get scattered back to interfere with the main beam This fraction is what ultimately shows up as glitches If the stray light path length was constant it wouldn't be a problem the backscattered light may be out of phase with the main beam but that's no different from one test mass being a tiny wee little bit in the wrong place which would be automatically corrected But since the reflecting item would be moving relative to the test mass the stray light path length will also change and the phase relationship between the backscattered light and the main beam will change If the stray light path length changes by say s which is approximately laser wavelengths per second we'll get visible noise at about Hz Moreover multiple reflections can cause the stray light path to be traversed multiple times and then we'll also get visible noise at higher frequencies stacks of parallel arches The top of an arch always corresponds to the moment when the reflecting item was moving fastest in one direction or the other relative to the test mass At moments when the motion stops and turns around the arches descend off the bottom of our images The hunt for the causes involves careful analysis of videos of the near infrared light and actively shaking the beam tubes and measuring the effects both with accelerometers mounted on the beam tubes and chambers and in the light that ultimately reaches the detection photodiodes One recent logbook entry among many is LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep continuing an investigation started in March in LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep Two infrared still photos attached to comments on the latter logbook entry LIGO Livingston's X end test mass in its suspension center seen from rear left to its right is the suspended reaction mass with circular electrostatic actuator traces plated on it the angular structure on the left is the Arm Cavity Baffle All of the illumination captured here by the camera comes from stray laser light ! LLO ETMX quad https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg Those gold plated electrostatic traces used to be the reflecting item responsible for the classic multi arch Scattered Light glitches during past observing runs This has been addressed since January by more carefully steering the suspensions to keep the distance between each test mass and the reaction mass behind it very nearly constant Any remaining glitches from this path would now occur below Hz where we won't see them in our subject images Looking a little further to the left with the test mass out of view beyond the right edge we now have the Arm Cavity Baffle on the right the cryopump baffle with two glints on its right edge left of center and a on the left a rather bright double glint off a spool piece where there's a large gate valve in the X arm beam tube The corner station would be km further away at rear left ! LLO glints near the end of the X arm https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg 600x tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG uploads DSCF jpeg Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab https www ligo caltech edu page image use policy The cryopump baffle is unlikely to be "it" they used to vibrate quite a lot in the presence of elevated ground motion levels and they were responsible for a lot of glitches during O but steps have since been taken to prevent them from vibrating The spool piece might be "it" but this has neither been proven nor ruled out yet The changes in the light path length implied by the frequencies of our arches seem a bit too large for it the spool piece shouldn't be able to move that much Hope this helps a little! By the way note that we don't see the main beam in these images There are more than kW of laser light circulating along earch arm between the reflecting surfaces of the input and end test masses but everything is happening inside a hard vacuum Thus there are next to no air molecules anywhere between the test masses that would scatter some light out of the beam towards the camera as they would if the beam was travelling in air https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ This is a rather common form that Scattered Light glitches from Hanford have been taking during the ongoing fourth observing run No well formed arches just wavy more or less parallel bits and fragments at frequencies mostly between and Hz sometimes with additional pieces between and Hz The band between and Hz tends to appear dark in most of our images It is blanketed by loud stationary noise which gets suppressed before our spectrogram images are created Only the loudest glitches manage to exceed the background noise in this band and show up there as well https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Very cool! So a lot of parts reflect just not into the recieving sensor? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Yes a lot of things inside the vacuum vessels are shiny and reflective One can't simply paint everything flat black paints don't go well with vacuum Paint molecules would evaporate drift around and settle somewhere else even on the test masses where we absolutely don't want them The baffles get special coatings of non smooth light absorbing materials and even then their edges can still reflect some light But the total area of the large vacuum chambers and long beam tubes is just too much to treat it all in this way That said the mirrors which are meant to reflect light in the intended directions are of exceedingly high quality and almost all of the light does go where it is meant to go The coatings on the end test masses reflect more than of the laser light! And the few parts per million that get through these coatings aren't wasted They are captured by additional optics behind the test masses and are used to measure the circulating light power and the beam position and angle https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Very cool! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Baby koi school https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423913/ School of melted blips https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423915/ Scattered light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423919/ School koi plus ? enough good representative subjects to take Cairn a step forward All collection subjects so far are rendered with Q value except subject https www zooniverse org with Q value The initial duration upper boundary of about seems now short to me As duration goes up to in gold set subject https www zooniverse org I collected subjects up to about to get a broader view but they might turn out to be borderline It keeps hinting at a small underlying population in L O so far Observations Gold subject https www zooniverse org like some others differs at Q value in that the alignment of the right end of the upper stacking lines in frame recedes in a slant downwards to the right side instead of filling up the frame from side to side Frame follows suit remaining asymmetrical The other population of glitches filling up frame from side to side in general has a well balanced right left view of the mound sides in frame as in mirror symmetry though not in perfect reflection A couple of such starboard morphologies as I nicknamed them showed up in searches fitting the other requirements so I included them in my L O collection These happen both in O4a and O4b sometimes in reverse port formation receding in a slant downwards to the left side of the spectrogram towards the "bow These morphologies happen to be also present in both collections by ZngabitanT L ER O4a Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a cairn and L ER O4b Cairn https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b cairn At this point I am unsure as to what is expected from Cairn O in this regard how asymmetrical the shape can be As a gold subject shows this pattern I feel that the description mound and alike are not exact being a certain mirror symmetry expected Real cairns range from perfectly symmetrical structures to crumbled or dispersed collections of rocks so perhaps a mound does not describe all the asymmetrical variations appearing in Q value and sometimes Q value Ongoing Question The following is a question I still have from the beginning and makes it more difficult for me to form a clearer concept about the Cairn morphology at Q and at times Q Do we need at least two prominent lines to form a Cairn shape? For example a one line subject is gold subject https www zooniverse org and subject https www zooniverse org in my collection In my opinion a cairn should need several prominent elements piled up not just a slightly curved single line Hence do we consider the very faint lines as defining elements? One possibility I've been mulling over and which may turn out to be wrong is that Cairns might be another part of the same population as Vibration Eruptions tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 1009409?comment where in the latter case the reflecting item the cryopump baffles used to be the prime suspect would be vibrating with larger amplitude thus upconverting the noise to higher frequencies at the culmination and as a byproduct also raising the decay phase which lasts a few seconds to frequencies above Hz where it doesn't get completely drowned out by the stationary background noise Like Cairns Vibration Eruptions attract renderings at a variety of Q values and they are roughly equally rare In this light it is interesting that you've picked up three in between subjects that I would be inclined to file under Vibration Eruption ! the examples in the glitch selection be updated? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424979/ Tiny high frequency glitch https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425678/ That depends We've had a few genuine Power Line glitches from Livingston during O so far which tend to look like these with a characteristic pair of "eyes" and with varying amounts of spillover to other frequencies ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 518fc c aa 9b 996198c f png tab ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 8 b 00ac b 132 f png tab ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 98a cbf 36d 4 d 9b dbf png tab They are caused by some Hz alternating current circuit switching on and off or off and on faster than the line subtraction filtering can follow The ever present Hz noise will be momentarily overcompensated then undercompensated then overcompensated again The stationary Hz noise mostly couples through magnetic fields There's a number of voltage monitors current monitors and magnetometers deployed and for each of them the correlation to the differential arm length measurements is known and periodically re measured and used to calibrate the subtraction But any filtering or subtraction confined to a very narrow frequency band necessarily takes time to react to changing conditions And while the subtraction is good overall or else the Hz peak in the noise spectrum would be much higher! it isn't perfect the actual coupling sites aren't quite where the magnetometers are You might enjoy skimming the paper P Nguyen al Environmental Noise in Advanced LIGO Detectors tab https arxiv org pdf PDF arXiv astro ph IM Classical and Quantum Gravity Volume Number But there are also other kinds of glitches at adjacent frequencies unrelated to the electricity mains and not covered by the Hz mitigation E The suspensions of some auxiliary optics have a "bounce mode" resonance near Hz which can show up tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk at multiples thereof including Hz ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location a 96b 41ef c png tab Between and Livingston experienced a series of very varied glitches tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3314162?comment that seriously impacted the sensitivity mostly with peak frequencies of Hz or multiples thereof Some of these could look deceptively like Hz "line" noise ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 8caa 41d bc a png tab After a lot of noise hunting by the engineers the cause for these along a complicated coupling path turned out tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep to be a single signal cable somewhere in the squeezer subsystem that was plugged tab https en wikipedia org wiki D subminiature into an electronics chassis but not properly fastened with both screws tightened https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Footnote Narrowband noise spectral lines are dealt with in different ways on different time scales The published data on GWOSC have been carefully cleaned offline over the course of months after the end of each observing run The near realtime data on which the plots on the status summary pages are based have undergone near realtime cleaning which since it needs to be fast and has to rely on estimates extrapolations of slowly changing parameters can't be quite as good The Omicron software looks for glitches in a raw data stream that hasn't yet been line cleaned Gravity Spy subject images are created from the same raw data after a preprocessing "whitening" step which somewhat imperfectly subdues any noise which looks stationary on timescales of around one minute So what we see in our subject images is based on a cruder form of line noise suppression than the data that are later uploaded to GWOSC https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Panoptes authentication uses a secure cookie That been true since the Panoptes API launched in Session cookies are used for some other bits of user personalisation like remembering whether you prefer a light or dark theme User preferences aren dated so I can see which workflow you last worked on but I don know if that was last week or last year That leads to bugs most notably a project team sends out an email with a link to their classify page previous volunteers follow the link and their preferences load a completed workflow This in turn leads to excess classifications on subjects that have already been completed https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ Ok thank you for the clarification! We'll see how this plays out then https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ One improvement that has been made in the new code is that you can link directly to specific workflows by workflow ID That a lot more reliable than trying to guess from user preferences eg https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy classify workflow 1610 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ At some point they will be once the detector engineers and the machine learning experts have reached a consensus about how best to address the needs At the present time it isn't even clear yet how best to carve up the glitches lately caused by scattered light into classes that are on the one hand amenable to classifying by their images limited to frequencies above Hz and to seconds' worth on the time axis and on the other hand make sense from an engineering perspective Considering the impact on clean observing time glitches which remain confined below Hz do less harm than glitches showing up at higher frequencies From this angle it might make sense to maintain the distinction between Scattered Light with arches visible above Hz and Low Frequency Burst without such even though the same causes are at work From a cause hunting angle lumping them together looks more attractive From a mitigation angle if something can be done to push the arches below Hz it would already be considered good progress and once again separate classes would help to measure the benefits And from an ML angle the current neural network is struggling to make sense of edge cases like tab or tab but also with obvious rows of arches la Livingston O ! frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 300x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location fd b f 4 d 84a fc png tab Upgrading and retraining the ML would help along with selecting new sets of example illustrations and of gold standard subjects along the way but would make it hard to compare future ML and volunteer classifications to existing ML and volunteer classifications of older subjects unless all the older subjects are also reprocessed and the Detector Characterization team expends extra time to familiarize themselves with the revised results So there is no easy win We've learned many lessons over the years and there are certainly things we'd do differently if we were to start over from scratch including better ways to adapt to unforeseen changes in the glitch mix For the moment we'll have to live within the limitations of the existing ML design use our human eyes and brains trained by millions of years of evolution to recognize ripe fruit and tiger stripes behind the foliage build representative collections and keep working on gradually improving the whole affair And your input is much appreciated! Indeed this was a completely new kind of glitch tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk first noted from LIGO Hanford on The cause remains unkown In late April another series of similar looking glitches happened again at Hanford during a couple of days And then from until we got a few hundred somewhat similar glitches from Livingston two of which are among your similarity search results In that case the cause is known it turned out tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep to be a single signal cable somewhere in the squeezer subsystem that was plugged tab https en wikipedia org wiki D subminiature into an electronics chassis but not properly fastened with both screws tightened Glitches from all three of these episodes have attracted a mix of low Q and high Q renderings so they differ widely in appearance If you want to see for yourself how a Blip changes in appearance under different rendering choices let's take one from O where the precise event timestamps and raw data have been published by now Head to the glitch plotter tab https gwo glitch plotter streamlit app ask it to load say seconds of data from H around timestamp 13T UTC GPS as it will compute for you and then scroll down both the navigation pane on the left and the panel with the plots on the right and pick different Q values with the slider and apply them The corresponding Gravity Spy subject is tab The same can be done with a published Binary Black Hole BBH chirp from O say GW tab https gwosc org eventapi html GWTC confident GW v which corresponds to subjects tab and tab Use 09T has the event time Enjoy! I have seen it when doing sim searches and should have asked this years ago It is something I doubt I will ever need to use but I am interested where it fits in to the whole AI ML scheme of things Please is there a VERY basic explanation? Thank you No hurry! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Sorry to hear it I have passed the message on to the person who developed the promotion system and hope to have a fix soon https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ When I check though it says you are in level Could you reload the site and see what levels are unlocked? Or is it promotion to level that's not working? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ Promotion to level is not working https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ A Convolutional Neural Network tab https en wikipedia org wiki Convolutional neural network ConvNN for short sometimes CNN for even shorter is a computer program which aims to simulate a network of nerve cells wired together in ways somewhat similar to those in our retinas and brain which underlie our sense of vision Among the different approaches to Machine Learning this is one particularly suited to image processing and therefore the one chosen for the Gravity Spy ML The simulated cells are arranged in layers The given image is divided into arrays of overlapping little squares The image data in each square are fed into one of the cells in the first layer Each of these input cells reacts to left right or up down or diagonal gradients brightness variations in its input square this is the "convolutional" part The outputs of the first layer cells in all sorts of combinations are processed further by the next layers Each successive layer is able to detect more complicated combinations of image traits straight or curved edges small or large uniform regions arches parallel streaks fuzziness Nessie coils After some four or five or six intermediate layers the final output layer consists of one cell for each glitch class or whatever one is trying to classify The one that "shouts most loudly" determines the label that will be attached to the image and how loudly it "shouts" compared to the others provides a confidence estimate During training the connections among the layers are strengthened or weakened at random until the outputs delivered on the training images agree reasonably well with the intended classifications This too aims to imitate how we understand learning to happen in real brains Hope this is suitably basic! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Among the various O "NotNoGlitch" subjects a few hundred mostly from Hanford O4b stand out They have peak frequencies near or near Hz and are readily tied to logbook entries about rung up violin modes The Machine Learning has been calling them No Glitch and indeed there's nothing much to see yet Omicron had triggered on them as excess noise with SNRs above or else they wouldn't exist as Gravity Spy subjects But it turns out that they don't actually represent glitches in the strain channel They represent elevated stationary noise levels in DARM and strain varying only gradually on time scales of minutes to hours They really originate as glitches in the glitch detection itself Thus I'm documenting them here as a distinct subclass of Violin Mode Harmonics Proposed Name LIGO O Invisible Violins ID of proposer ZngabitanT Date of proposal Reference subjects for Classifier and Field Guide S holotype linked above info ?username zngabitant collection display name l er a invisible violins H ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu collection info collection info ?username zngabitant collection display name h er b invisible violins L ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu collection info collection info ?username zngabitant collection display name l er b invisible violins by ZngabitanT Collaborators dianasironi mitchnanny moderators researchers Remarks In fact not only is there an unusual excess of overlapping pairs of subjects these pairs also straddle full second boundaries at one minute intervals The examples from all come just before or just after a GPS second that fell seconds after a multiple of Those from all happened seconds after a multiple of On the other hand the seconds periodicity tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk of the Pizzicato glitches from O has disappeared completely Example pairs more will keep turning up from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab and from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab What must have been happening here is that Omicron in the presence of a rung up violin mode or other loud stationary narrowband noise tends to trigger near the end of its current seconds chunk of data and then again near the beginning of the next seconds chunk Sometimes only one member of such a pair of triggers will exceed the SNR > threshold for creating a Gravity Spy subject Sometimes both would remain too faint to show up here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ So what to do about these triggers? Are they useful? Are they necessary? Could we do without them? The observatory operators and the data quality team on their weekly shifts don't need them rung up violin modes are reported in other more direct ways They do add some spice to the Gravity Spy volunteer experience One more sort of thing that requires taking a closer look and extracting the peak frequency using the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools ciera northwestern edu search and a satisfyingly successful trip to the LIGO logbooks for corroboration But of course our personal enlightenment isn't the primary objective of the glitch detection software It is likely that they could be avoided by padding the minute long data chunks on which Omicron operates with shoulders of at least seconds on both sides my experience whilst working with the glitch plotter tab https gwo glitch plotter streamlit app has been that I needed this much padding in order for the whitening to work satisfactorily and to avoid artefacts near the beginning and end of data chunks But this would increase the latency in the time critical path for vetoing candidate events that are accompanied by glitches in safe auxiliary channels So it may be better to keep things as they are and live with these "glitches" It's worth noting that the Virgo team had encountered a very similar issue at the beginning of O tab https logbook virgo gw eu virgo ?r and tuned the padding and overlap duration for their Omicron installation in April and again in June tab https logbook virgo gw eu virgo ?r And we had seen similar evenly spaced pairs of overlapping "NotNoGlitch" subjects from Virgo O https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ The images fed to the GravitySpy ML ConvNN day in day out while the observatories are Observing are the same that then get uploaded to Zooniverse as subjects for us to inspect except that the ML gets to "view" all four frames at once side by side and without the title texts colourmap axis tick marks and labels only the four spectrogram images themselves For re training purposes it would be fed a set of around a hundred such images carefully selected and believed to be representative of a single new glitch class In reality it's somewhat more complicated The set is split up randomly into a larger part used for the training phase and a smaller part for testing validation Then the current training subset is run through the neural network adjusting the cell connections in the process and the outcome is evaluated on the current test subset while keeping the connections fixed And then this is repeated with a new random splitting of the given subject set many times until the results no longer improve in further iterations The sort of language oriented AI that has been getting headlines in the last year and a half ChatGPT and friends works completely differently though The only commonalities are that they also run on computers and also need to be trained But they require vastly larger amounts of training data and existing Large Language Models have been trained on data of sometimes extremely dubious quality not to mention copyright infringements on a global scale https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ No doubt people will want to know about ChatGPT I have never used it but have actually heard about it Thank you for your as I see it I began a collection on these events Thank you https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Pretty catch! The title subject is a rare Q rendering of a flock as is The remainder of the sim search results is something of a mixed bunch Since the choice of Q value has such a large effect on the general texture of the resulting subject images the Similarity Search tool tends to be more sensitive to the Q value than to the glitch class And since flocks at Q are rare it returns an eclectic mix of other things instead Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Whether you're browsing recent pages or viewing the results of a logbook search is specific to your current browser session and can't be exported through a URL The link you see in the URL field of your browser when you're looking at the search results ends up pointing at the logbook start page for everyone else No loss in the present case since flocks aren't momentous enough as glitches go to earn specific logbook mentions Only individual logbook entries and comments on them can be linked to directly Their URLs can be captured for pasting by using the browser's "Copy link" function on the "Link" button in the entry heading https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429011/ Nice catch! This and similar subjects mostly from Hanford with brief sometimes repeating noise near and or around Hz are None Of The Above Sometimes we call them "Pirate Ships" by a superficial analogy with the old Virgo O glitch class of that name At Hanford they are caused by beam jitter they show up when the laser beam already wobbles sideways a little at the point where it enters the first vacuum chamber The subset near Hz got almost completely fixed in October the others still occur occasionally They are relatively rare They may yet earn a formal glitch class proposal once we've collected enough examples https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429184/ Another kind of None Of The Above These require a glance at the Similarity Search tool tab https gravityspytools Last year there were occasional hiccups with the subject upload process which resulted in repeated upload attempts and thus in accidental duplications and it has not been feasible to clean up completely afterwards The present glitch is one of that happened between and at Hanford cause unknown and not related to locklosses but nearly each of them was uploaded to Zooniverse five times under five different subject numbers without making it into the Gravity Spy tools before finally being successfully uploaded a sixth time The good and usable subjects from those days have numbers 9636xxxx the earlier 9287xxxx through 9343xxxx should be considered as extraneous duplicates If we were to remove them from Zooniverse now we would also orphan the associated Talk threads and produce inconsistencies in any collections containing them The usable version of the present subject is tab As to how to deal with the duplicates I would frown at them flag them as such by adding them to suitable marker collections and move on to the next subject There's also a small handful of subjects showing other kinds of glitches of which two or more copies exist in the Similarity Seach database and these can produce a different nondescript error when one asks for fewer results than the number of copies There used to be many more during O many subjects had been ingested four or five times and there was one that had got uploaded more than a thousand times those had been cleared out at one point leaving only one representative subject of each glitch Clearing out the few that exist at the present time would require a disproportionate amount of manual effort so we've left them alone https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ oki thanks for clarification! What's less cool from a LIGO engineer's point of view is that this has been the most common type of glitch at Livingston since the beginning of the fourth observing run in May and it is still not clear how exactly these glitches arise We no longer get the sort of multi arch Scattered Light that was common in past years and that's illustrated in the Field Guide that sort was root caused in late tab The two arches are separated by a darker band covering Hz punctuated by three evenly spaced streaks tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk that's a region where there's a lot of always present stationary background noise which gets suppressed before our images are created So it's a new variant of lower frequency Scattered Light but it's unclear where the scattering happens at the corner station or near one of the two test masses at the ends of the arms and it's unclear what the reflecting item is that's moving relative to the test masses https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Huh so if I understand it correctly something is moving which causes the laser to move slightly thus registering as a "quake" I don't know the appropiate terminolgy sorry and you don't yet know what exactly is moving?
