it I began a collection on these events https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Pretty catch! The title subject is a rare Q rendering of a flock as is The remainder of the sim search results is something of a mixed bunch Since the choice of Q value has such a large effect on the general texture of the resulting subject images the Similarity Search tool tends to be more sensitive to the Q value than to the glitch class And since flocks at Q are rare it returns an eclectic mix of other things instead Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Whether you're browsing recent pages or viewing the results of a logbook search is specific to your current browser session and can't be exported through a URL The link you see in the URL field of your browser when you're looking at the search results ends up pointing at the logbook start page for everyone else No loss in the present case since flocks aren't momentous enough as glitches go to earn specific logbook mentions Only individual logbook entries and comments on them can be linked to directly Their URLs can be captured for pasting by using the browser's "Copy link" function on the "Link" button in the entry heading https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ for the feedback and information An eclectic mix indeed as sim search sees it I took a look at the array of subjects tagged with "flock" there is a wide variety of glitches making up a flock seems pretty special > Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Yes I recalled something about this from previous logbook searches seeing that my draft post returned the Home page after having pasted the URL on top of the search results even though that search URL contained the corresponding "page 1" and "page 2" appended yet switched to the Home page when pasted into the address bar Many thanks! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ ! channel are classic multi arch Scattered Light the kind that was still common during most of the third observing run before it got fixed in January The auxiliary channel which monitors the light circulating in the X arm represented by the few parts per million of it which make it through the mirror coatings on the end test mass and then get captured by the optics of the transmission monitoring system didn't witness it on this occasion The present S is a counterpart to S https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429011/ Nice catch! This and similar subjects mostly from Hanford with brief sometimes repeating noise near and or around Hz are None Of The Above Sometimes we call them "Pirate Ships" by a superficial analogy with the old Virgo O glitch class of that name At Hanford they are caused by beam jitter they show up when the laser beam already wobbles sideways a little at the point where it enters the first vacuum chamber The subset near Hz got almost completely fixed in October the others still occur occasionally They are relatively rare They may yet earn a formal glitch class proposal once we've collected enough examples https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429184/ Another kind of None Of The Above These require a glance at the Similarity Search tool tab ended https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429187/ To clarify this is primarily a gold standard example of Repeating Blips intended to familiarize volunteers in the level workflow with cases where groups of individual glitchlets need to be treated as a whole and where it is essential to look at the fourth frame and take in the whole picture And I agree on the central constituent blip being slightly mis shapen because it is coincidentally blended with a bit of unrelated lower frequency noise In some cases ancient subjects that had already been uploaded once before the Gravity Spy tools existed to serve as gold standard examples were uploaded a second time later as ordinary subjects with new subject numbers and were then also added to the Similarity Search tool's database Thus Sim Search won't find the present subject under its original number but a search for the character subject id uniqueid IdrpGAG37s will succeed and will find the copy with subject number Note that the image was reprocessed for this purpose In the newer copy the image title mentions the first observing run O explicitly Apologies for the invoncenience! Last year there were occasional hiccups with the subject upload process which resulted in repeated upload attempts and thus in accidental duplications and it has not been feasible to clean up completely afterwards The present glitch is one of that happened between and at Hanford cause unknown and not related to locklosses but nearly each of them was uploaded to Zooniverse five times under five different subject numbers without making it into the Gravity Spy tools before finally being successfully uploaded a sixth time The good and usable subjects from those days have numbers 9636xxxx the earlier 9287xxxx through 9343xxxx should be considered as extraneous duplicates If we were to remove them from Zooniverse now we would also orphan the associated Talk threads and produce inconsistencies in any collections containing them The usable version of the present subject is tab As to how to deal with the duplicates I would frown at them flag them as such by adding them to suitable marker collections and move on to the next subject There's also a small handful of subjects showing other kinds of glitches of which two or more copies exist in the Similarity Seach database and these can produce a different nondescript error when one asks for fewer results than the number of copies There used to be many more during O many subjects had been ingested four or five times and there was one that had got uploaded more than a thousand times those had been cleared out at one point leaving only one representative subject of each glitch Clearing out the few that exist at the present time would require a disproportionate amount of manual effort so we've left them alone https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ oki thanks for clarification! Recently I started getting glitches from this sequence one after another but was unable to find any info in Talk Btw how did you manage to find usable version of the subject in question? Definitely not by brute forcing subject IDs matching right? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Yes well observed you'll see this in a number of ancient subjects If I am not mistaken the reason is that back then well before my time the normalized noise energy was fed into the colormap as is whereas more recent subjects use the logarithm of the normalized energy which will show some finer glitch details as well as the random background more clearly Noise levels within a single subject image can vary by five orders of magnitude even after the removal of stationary noise "whitening" during preprocessing https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429884/ One of our veteran volunteers who is currently taking a break from Zooniverse had collected almost all of these two hundred something Hz glitch subjects as they come up whilst classifying Once our systematic similarity searches across the good ones found no further examples it was a matter of looking at each of the good ones in turn find its exact copies in the twenty odd collection pages where twelve subject per page are displayed write down the relationships in an offline file and remove the copies from the bulk collection so this eyeball search became easier with each glitch that we had dealt with A few duplicates had been missed and only showed up later and these could be tied in by eyeballing the collection of good representatives which fits on pages https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Can someone shed some light on what to classify this one please? None Of The Above is always an option whenever something doesn't want to fit easily into the available classes And this is often the case at present During the fourth observing run that's now in progress after three years of upgrades tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2800503?comment the LIGO interferometers have been producing a glitch mix that's very different from anything we had seen before Some old glitch classes still occur in recognizable forms some still occur but look different some no longer occur and quite a few completely new things tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk have been coming up The present subject comes from a brief episode on tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk when one of Livingston's feedback control loops had failed and over the course of a mere three minutes the interferometer drifted so far from its working point that the lock was lost We already see multiple things going on at once here repeating blips violin mode harmonics a wandering line While it's not at all obvious it was one of the repeating blips that triggered this subject But None Of The Above is certainly appropriate too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430118/ None Of The Above They were a completely new and unexpected thing tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk when they suddenly started happening in large numbers during three days in late May and early June https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3000650/ Well noted! Again I would recommend None Of The Above These Hz glitches were another new thing when they showed up on at Hanford and then stopped happening again at the end of the month Only such glitches seem to have been recorded too few to justify a formal glitch class proposal the cause remains a mystery Around that time there were hiccups with the uploading of subjects to the Gravity Spy tools tab The Ripples have not reoccurred in the 3rd and 4th observing runs but there are some lookalikes that have been confusing the Gravity Spy Machine Learning too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430133/ Yet another type of None Of The Above! These mini jolts like the Hz glitches come from beam jitter when the laser beam wobbles sideways by a tiny amount already before it enters the first vacuum chamber On this particular occasion on technicians had been pulling fiber cables under the raised floors near the control room to connect a fire alarm panel The connection to these glitches was soon noted tab Why not start a collection of these? It will come in helpful There isn't a formal glitch class proposal for these jitter glitches yet but I guess there have been enough of them to justify one once we can support it with collections of representative subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430142/ They would have been visible when they occurred on their own thanks to the energy normalization but not when anything louder was also present https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429884/ Well observed! What's less cool from a LIGO engineer's point of view is that this has been the most common type of glitch at Livingston since the beginning of the fourth observing run in May and it is still not clear how exactly these glitches arise We no longer get the sort of multi arch Scattered Light that was common in past years and that's illustrated in the Field Guide that sort was root caused in late tab The two arches are separated by a darker band covering Hz punctuated by three evenly spaced streaks tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk that's a region where there's a lot of always present stationary background noise which gets suppressed before our images are created So it's a new variant of lower frequency Scattered Light but it's unclear where the scattering happens at the corner station or near one of the two test masses at the ends of the arms and it's unclear what the reflecting item is that's moving relative to the test masses https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Huh so if I understand it correctly something is moving which causes the laser to move slightly thus registering as a "quake" I don't know the appropiate terminolgy sorry and you don't yet know what exactly is moving? Something weird happened here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Yes! We're living on a restless planet Even aside from earthquakes strong enough to be felt the ground beneath our feet is always in motion at speeds of up to about a micrometer per second caused by a mix of weak distant earthquakes wind driven ocean wave activity human activity plus gusts of wind leaning on building walls which then lean on the pillars which support them which then causes the floor under the pillars to tilt a little LIGO's vacuum chambers and the beam tubes connecting them along with anything attached to the walls of the vacuum vessels follow these ground motions Inside four of the large vacuum chambers at each site there are the test masses in their four stage "quad" pendulum suspensions mounted on a three stage internal seismic isolation structure mounted in turn on a hydraulic external pre isolation For some pictures of the hardware see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk So the test masses move a whole lot less than everything around them Between the polished mirror coated front surfaces of the test masses in each arm the main laser beams are circulating Tiny imperfections of the coatings cause a tiny fraction of the laser light to be scattered out of the beams in arbitrary directions Most of the stray light hits one of many baffles and is absorbed A tiny fraction of the stray light however may hit something reflective attached to the walls which are moving relative to the test masses A tiny fraction of the reflected light may hit the nearest test mass again and get scattered back to interfere with the main beam This fraction is what ultimately shows up as glitches If the stray light path length was constant it wouldn't be a problem the backscattered light may be out of phase with the main beam but that's no different from one test mass being a tiny wee little bit in the wrong place which would be automatically corrected But since the reflecting item would be moving relative to the test mass the stray light path length will also change and the phase relationship between the backscattered light and the main beam will change If the stray light path length changes by say s which is approximately laser wavelengths per second we'll get visible noise at about Hz Moreover multiple reflections can cause the stray light path to be traversed multiple times and then we'll also get visible noise at higher frequencies stacks of parallel arches The top of an arch always corresponds to the moment when the reflecting item was moving fastest in one direction or the other relative to the test mass At moments when the motion stops and turns around the arches descend off the bottom of our images The hunt for the causes involves careful analysis of videos of the near infrared light and actively shaking the beam tubes and measuring the effects both with accelerometers mounted on the beam tubes and chambers and in the light that ultimately reaches the detection photodiodes One recent logbook entry among many is LLO tab LIGO Livingston's X end test mass in its suspension center seen from rear left to its right is the suspended reaction mass with circular electrostatic actuator traces plated on it the angular structure on the left is the Arm Cavity Baffle All of the illumination captured here by the camera comes from stray laser light ! LLO ETMX quad Those gold plated electrostatic traces used to be the reflecting item responsible for the classic multi arch Scattered Light glitches during past observing runs This has been addressed since January by more carefully steering the suspensions to keep the distance between each test mass and the reaction mass behind it very nearly constant Any remaining glitches from this path would now occur below Hz where we won't see them in our subject images Looking a little further to the left with the test mass out of view beyond the right edge we now have the Arm Cavity Baffle on the right the cryopump baffle with two glints on its right edge left of center and a on the left a rather bright double glint off a spool piece where there's a large gate valve in the X arm beam tube The corner station would be km further away at rear left ! LLO glints near the end of the X arm Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab The cryopump baffle is unlikely to be "it" they used to vibrate quite a lot in the presence of elevated ground motion levels and they were responsible for a lot of glitches during O but steps have since been taken to prevent them from vibrating The spool piece might be "it" but this has neither been proven nor ruled out yet The changes in the light path length implied by the frequencies of our arches seem a bit too large for it the spool piece shouldn't be able to move that much Hope this helps a little! By the way note that we don't see the main beam in these images There are more than kW of laser light circulating along earch arm between the reflecting surfaces of the input and end test masses but everything is happening inside a hard vacuum Thus there are next to no air molecules anywhere between the test masses that would scatter some light out of the beam towards the camera as they would if the beam was travelling in air https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ This is a rather common form that Scattered Light glitches from Hanford have been taking during the ongoing fourth observing run No well formed arches just wavy more or less parallel bits and fragments at frequencies mostly between and Hz sometimes with additional pieces between and Hz The band between and Hz tends to appear dark in most of our images It is blanketed by loud stationary noise which gets suppressed before our spectrogram images are created Only the loudest glitches manage to exceed the background noise in this band and show up there as well https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Very cool! So a lot of parts reflect just not into the recieving sensor? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Yes a lot of things inside the vacuum vessels are shiny and reflective One can't simply paint everything flat black paints don't go well with vacuum Paint molecules would evaporate drift around and settle somewhere else even on the test masses where we absolutely don't want them The baffles get special coatings of non smooth light absorbing materials and even then their edges can still reflect some light But the total area of the large vacuum chambers and long beam tubes is just too much to treat it all in this way That said the mirrors which are meant to reflect light in the intended directions are of exceedingly high quality and almost all of the light does go where it is meant to go The coatings on the end test masses reflect more than of the laser light! And the few parts per million that get through these coatings aren't wasted They are captured by additional optics behind the test masses and are used to measure the circulating light power and the beam position and angle https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Very cool! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Baby koi school https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423913/ School of melted blips https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423915/ Scattered light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423919/ School koi plus ? One possibility I've been mulling over and which may turn out to be wrong is that Cairns might be another part of the same population as Vibration Eruptions tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 1009409?comment where in the latter case the reflecting item the cryopump baffles used to be the prime suspect would be vibrating with larger amplitude thus upconverting the noise to higher frequencies at the culmination and as a byproduct also raising the decay phase which lasts a few seconds to frequencies above Hz where it doesn't get completely drowned out by the stationary background noise Like Cairns Vibration Eruptions attract renderings at a variety of Q values and they are roughly equally rare In this light it is interesting that you've picked up three in between subjects that I would be inclined to file under Vibration Eruption ! This is a good question and I don't know the answer After one of the hundreds of feedback control loops that normally cooperate to maintain a good lock had failed outright when one camera monitoring the beam alignment had stopped working there were multiple unusual things going on at once By the time the present subject was recorded a couple minutes later the Livingston interferometer had already drifted so far from its intended working point that a lockloss was less than seconds away Bits and pieces of this wandering line are visible in a number of subjects from the surrounding minutes tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk I haven't seen anything similar to it in any Livingston O subjects recorded in more normal conditions Do watch out though for a Wandering Line undulating more slowly in a few dozen Hanford O subjects from last January https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3064584/ Yes to fixes applied a few years ago most of it nowadays happens below the Hz bottom edge of our spectrograms we only get to see the topmost parts of the action https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424979/ NOTA is fine when something doesn't want to fit into the available classes This subject shows a coincidental mix of two different independent glitches The tall central feature with hints of "lighthouse" decorations could be called a Blip although it's a bit of a stretch if it had been louder it would turn into a kind of Extremely Loud The "wheatgrass" surrounding it below Hz is a form of Scattered Light rendered as rows of beatnote pulses here because this subject was processed with very fine time resolution at the expense of very coarse frequency resolution The "fins" of a Koi Fish would look somewhat similar but more symmetric and at slightly higher frequencies https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ The raw data are recorded at a rate of samples per second so frequencies up to Hz could be extracted with some distortion and up to a little beyond Hz in sufficient quality to create images like ours this isn't normally done here since it costs extra memory and processing time and most glitches don't need it I don't have a timestamp for the present subject so I can't produce another image of this particular Whistle even though the raw data from the first three observing runs are public by now but see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2079928?comment page for some other examples and illustrations! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ Another great question! Some old examples aside it is safe to assume that every Gravity Spy subject from recent and ongoing observing runs contains a glitch or rarely a real gravitational wave chirp something that exceeded the ever present background noise levels by at least a factor of But that Something isn't always visible in the resulting image The Gravity Spy tools tab Watch out for other NotNoGlitch subjects There are many with reported peak frequencies around or around Hz betraying a violin mode origin quite a few from Hanford at or Hz which tend to belong into a proposed new class tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk some from Hanford at or Hz and more from Livingston at Hz which belong into another propopsed class tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk and some others https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ What happens when a participant chooses NOTA? Does it get sent to a higher level for further inspection? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ I just checked the datasets at gwosc to see if I could get the data from there but it looks like data from January to November is missing entirely? Why is this? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ First of all This is an extraneous subject there must exist another where the obvious extremely loud glitch appears properly centered I haven't seen it yet but it would probably look somewhat like tab recorded a day and a half earlier The difference in appearance is due to rendering choices coarse vs fine time resolution combined with fine vs coarse frequency resolution Why do we get such extraneous off center subjects? Mostly because the glitch detection software inspects minute long chunks of data at a time setting to work in near real time whenever another minute's worth of data has become available The "outskirts" of a loud glitch near the end of one chunk can then cause another spurious detection at the beginning of the next chunk as in this case or the onset of a loud glitch near the beginning of a fresh chunk can already have caused a spurious detection at the end of the preceding chunk Next This one did not cause a lockloss we see clean data with just the usual amount of faint random background noise everywhere in the right half of the fourth frame But similar glitches are among the loudest that a LIGO interferometer can with luck survive without losing its lock tab is one of the loudest such I've seen at an SNR above And even louder ones can cause a lockloss E this one did some seconds beyond the " s" right edge of the fourth frame ! frame What causes this kind of extremely loud glitches? Ultimately earthquakes or thunderclaps or very strong gusts of wind which despite the multi stage seismic isolation manage to cause one or more of the mirror suspensions to shake The feedback control loops which keep the arm length difference "DARM" constant to within a picometer a millionth of a micrometer and those which keep the test masses mirrors at their proper angles to allow the laser light to bounce back and forth between them more than a hundred times operate in a mode with limited actuation strength and low noise once the lock has been acquired They can compensate and damp some amount of unwanted motion but not a lot When more force would be needed than is available things will momentarily depart from the proper working point resulting in a sudden LOT of noise in the data and a loudspeaker in the control room will automatically issue a verbal alert like "EX saturation!" to the operator With luck acting a little longer with the limited force available may still suffice to recover from the disturbance or it may not the lock may be lost a fast shutter closes within milliseconds to protect the detection photodiodes the input laser power is ramped down the remaining circulating laser light ends up in beam dumps and the lock would need to be reacquired slowly The saturation and lockloss illustrated above at 19T was caused by an earthquake and goes with LLO tab https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ In case of a no glitch should I use the tools to see if this is really the case and then report as NOTA if there is something? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ I'll have a look at the tools I assume these should only be used when the glitch class isn't clear? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ In the long run yes or it may just be kept around until all the newly discovered glitch classes have been studied sufficiently to re train the Machine Learning and to make some of them official so that further submissions can then mark them as "one of the above" And in any case NOTA ensures that more people are going to get a look! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ Because the first Observing Run of Advanced LIGO ended on and the second started on GWOSC only holds published data tab Engineering Runs are thus excluded weekly maintenance periods are excluded routine half hour calibration measurement periods are excluded and of course there are no data from times when the observatories weren't observing g recovering from a lockloss or weren't even running because of lengthy upgrades tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2800503?comment between observing runs https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ You mention SNR what is this a measurement of? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Ah ok so gravity spy uses all data? this subject is from https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ Ah ok how accurate has the algorithm gotten so far? Anywhere I can read up on this? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ It's up to you how deeply you want to delve into each subject! Sometimes Similarity Search provides insights that aren't easy to come by in other ways Personally I am going to some extremes but I certainly don't expect everybody else to do so I will run a "NotNoGlitch" subject through a similarity search for result immediately based on the character identifier which I can already access while classifying just to see whether it belongs under Violin Modes or Low Frequency Lines or somewhere else Otherwise I'll just make a note of the subject number to return to it later I would usually add a subject to an appropriate collection only after it has been returned as a result from a small similarity search starting from another subject by which time I would also have written down the peak frequency and other metadata and eyeballed an approximate timestamp to within minutes or so and then I feed the collected subject's number back into another sim search to keep my to do queues populated I also keep track of how often each subject has appeared as a sim search result In this way I can gradually build collections of the most representative subjects of each kind Cascades of many small searches asking for rather fewer than results each time tend to work much better for exploring an underlying populations than doing only a few searches asking for many results Of course the tool being image based mixes up all the NotNoGlitch subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ Signal to background Noise Ratio or in this case glitch noise level divided by background noise level https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ The "date" stamps of old subjects are dummy values reflecting the date on which the upload script was last modified Only since the fourth observing run do we have the real event date available through the nfo button Admittedly this is a little confusing but then almost all old subjects have been deactivated from the workflows in order to focus on the new material except for the gold standard subjects and for a selection of Whistles from O to make up for a total lack of Whistles from O so far The present subject dates from the first observing run and was uploaded to Zooniverse in October after results from a pilot phase of the budding project had been evaluated Subjects from later runs have the run number embedded in their titles after the observatory name https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ To be frank at the moment the Machine Learning is all over the place The glitch mix coming from the LIGO observatories during the ongoing fourth observing run differs very much from anything we've seen before and from everything the ML had previously been trained for We still have recognizable Blips and Koi Fish but Scattered Light looks very different now and there are many completely new things tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk and some new things that look deceptively similar to old glitch classes that haven't reoccurred in years or whose causes have been completely eliminated in the course of observatory upgrades And changing anything in the ML takes time tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3369772?comment One fairly recent paper is Y Wu al Advancing Glitch Classification in Gravity Spy Multi view Fusion with Attention based Machine Learning for Advanced LIGO's Fourth Observing Run tab You'll find this along with a selection of older material linked from Talk > Help > Resources tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk very much for your sustained interest! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ for the comprehensive answer! Just a question for my own understanding I'm aware that a fair amount of browser side Zooniverse state both PFE and FEM is cached in session storage Are cookies currently also being used for anything aside from authentication and statistics gathering? Or would this be the first use of cookies for maintaining functional state? Why I am asking is When a volunteer switches among several devices or among several different browsers browser profiles on one device session state for which the single source of truth is on the server side will be fetched and cached and the new session will be in sync with where the previous session had left off But cookies won't carry over This might cause surprises If there's already other functional state that's kept in cookies then I'd expect fewer surprises But if not then a solution based on the existing per user per project project preferences stored server side and cached browser side might be preferable in the long term so as to have all such features work in similar ways The server side project preferences already remember in which workflow of the project I've been active most recently and if I'm not mistaken they are already being fetched by both frontends when a classifier is launched so the information would be available to the frontends it's just not being used at the moment https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ I'll have a look at the paper you sent very much for the quick and helpful answers! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ Fair enough https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ So 95440075's glitch is times louder ? clearer? brighter? than the background? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Yes that's it "Louder" is probably the best word Astronomers speak of a binary neutron star merger as a " standard siren tab The SNR is computed in relation to the small random background fluctuations not in relation to the DC light level Also ever present stationary noise a lot of it esp at low frequencies but also at a number of fixed higher frequencies is removed before considering the random background and computing SNRs Here's a plot of yesterday's stationary background noise levels from the detector status summary page for the day tab ! IGWN sensitivity Some LIGO noise features you can find in there include suspension noise near and near and Hz a mostly subtracted out bunch of calibration lines around Hz the Hz mains frequency the violin modes of the beam splitter suspension near Hz and those of the test mass suspensions near Hz and multiples thereof Virgo's fundamental violin modes show up near Hz and multiples and Virgo's Hz mains subtraction has been doing a good job leaving only a modest peak in the violet curve The steep overall rise on the left is mostly due to a combination of seismic noise thermal noise radiation pressure noise on the test masses and residual motion of the suspensions The less steep rise on the right is shot noise from the detection photodiodes picking up the incoming light in discrete quanta already mitigated as far as possible by quantum squeezing tab https en wikipedia org wiki Squeezed states of light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ What causes 60hz glitches to appear even when mitigated? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/

https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ I ve updated the GitHub PR to explain how a SameSite cookie protects against accidentally loading the wrong workflow when following a link from an email or external site https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ As a matter of interest maybe to others like myself what on earth is ConvNN? I have seen it when doing sim searches and should have asked this years ago It is something I doubt I will ever need to use but I am interested where it fits in to the whole AI ML scheme of things Please is there a VERY basic explanation? No hurry! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Sorry to hear it I have passed the message on to the person who developed the promotion system and hope to have a fix soon https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ When I check though it says you are in level Could you reload the site and see what levels are unlocked? Or is it promotion to level that's not working? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ Promotion to level is not working https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ A Convolutional Neural Network tab The simulated cells are arranged in layers The given image is divided into arrays of overlapping little squares The image data in each square are fed into one of the cells in the first layer Each of these input cells reacts to left right or up down or diagonal gradients brightness variations in its input square this is the "convolutional" part The outputs of the first layer cells in all sorts of combinations are processed further by the next layers Each successive layer is able to detect more complicated combinations of image traits straight or curved edges small or large uniform regions arches parallel streaks fuzziness Nessie coils After some four or five or six intermediate layers the final output layer consists of one cell for each glitch class or whatever one is trying to classify The one that "shouts most loudly" determines the label that will be attached to the image and how loudly it "shouts" compared to the others provides a confidence estimate During training the connections among the layers are strengthened or weakened at random until the outputs delivered on the training images agree reasonably well with the intended classifications This too aims to imitate how we understand learning to happen in real brains Hope this is suitably basic! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Among the various O "NotNoGlitch" subjects a few hundred mostly from Hanford O4b stand out They have peak frequencies near or near Hz and are readily tied to logbook entries about rung up violin modes The Machine Learning has been calling them No Glitch and indeed there's nothing much to see yet Omicron had triggered on them as excess noise with SNRs above or else they wouldn't exist as Gravity Spy subjects But it turns out that they don't actually represent glitches in the strain channel They represent elevated stationary noise levels in DARM and strain varying only gradually on time scales of minutes to hours They really originate as glitches in the glitch detection itself Thus I'm documenting them here as a distinct subclass of Violin Mode Harmonics Proposed Name LIGO O Invisible Violins ID of proposer Date of proposal Reference subjects for Classifier and Field Guide S holotype linked above S S S ! frame showing the second frames Short description Nothing at all stands out visually Minor unrelated noise may be present The peak frequencies accessible through Similarity Search tab Characteristics As above SNRs rarely exceed All Q value choices can occur Overlapping pairs of subjects are unusually common see below Hash tags a Collections NB the metadata links do not work at present pending a DYCWMI tool bugfix but will work once the tool has been fixed no training set at this time since the current Machine Learning doesn't take Omicron metadata into account Bulk collections growing H ER O4a Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er a invisible violins link to its metadata tab L ER O4a Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a invisible violins link to its metadata tab H ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab L ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab Collaborators Remarks In fact not only is there an unusual excess of overlapping pairs of subjects these pairs also straddle full second boundaries at one minute intervals The examples from all come just before or just after a GPS second that fell seconds after a multiple of Those from all happened seconds after a multiple of On the other hand the seconds periodicity tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk of the Pizzicato glitches from O has disappeared completely Example pairs more will keep turning up from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab and from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab What must have been happening here is that Omicron in the presence of a rung up violin mode or other loud stationary narrowband noise tends to trigger near the end of its current seconds chunk of data and then again near the beginning of the next seconds chunk Sometimes only one member of such a pair of triggers will exceed the SNR > threshold for creating a Gravity Spy subject Sometimes both would remain too faint to show up here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ So what to do about these triggers? Are they useful? Are they necessary? Could we do without them? The observatory operators and the data quality team on their weekly shifts don't need them rung up violin modes are reported in other more direct ways They do add some spice to the Gravity Spy volunteer experience One more sort of thing that requires taking a closer look and extracting the peak frequency using the Similarity Search tool tab It is likely that they could be avoided by padding the minute long data chunks on which Omicron operates with shoulders of at least seconds on both sides my experience whilst working with the glitch plotter tab So it may be better to keep things as they are and live with these "glitches" It's worth noting that the Virgo team had encountered a very similar issue at the beginning of O tab O https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ For the record below I am listing documented episodes of rung up violin modes from which we've seen visible or invisible fallout as Gravity Spy subjects ER LHO LHO tab O4a LHO 04ff LHO tab LLO briefly very visible just before a lockloss see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk LHO and following ITMY mode and later Hz with a series of logbook entries including LHO tab LHO LHO tab LHO 28ff LHO tab LLO 28f LLO tab LHO LHO tab https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ ER none O4b LLO 15f LLO tab LHO LHO tab LHO LHO tab I have not yet seen any subjects from subequent episodes LHO LHO tab LLO LLO tab LLO 16ff LLO tab LLO 31ff LLO tab LLO LLO tab modes https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ The images fed to the GravitySpy ML ConvNN day in day out while the observatories are Observing are the same that then get uploaded to Zooniverse as subjects for us to inspect except that the ML gets to "view" all four frames at once side by side and without the title texts colourmap axis tick marks and labels only the four spectrogram images themselves For re training purposes it would be fed a set of around a hundred such images carefully selected and believed to be representative of a single new glitch class In reality it's somewhat more complicated The set is split up randomly into a larger part used for the training phase and a smaller part for testing validation Then the current training subset is run through the neural network adjusting the cell connections in the process and the outcome is evaluated on the current test subset while keeping the connections fixed And then this is repeated with a new random splitting of the given subject set many times until the results no longer improve in further iterations The sort of language oriented AI that has been getting headlines in the last year and a half ChatGPT and friends works completely differently though The only commonalities are that they also run on computers and also need to be trained But they require vastly larger amounts of training data and existing Large Language Models have been trained on data of sometimes extremely dubious quality not to mention copyright infringements on a global scale https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ No doubt people will want to know about ChatGPT I have never used it but have actually heard about it for your explanations it I began a collection on these events https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Pretty catch! The title subject is a rare Q rendering of a flock as is The remainder of the sim search results is something of a mixed bunch Since the choice of Q value has such a large effect on the general texture of the resulting subject images the Similarity Search tool tends to be more sensitive to the Q value than to the glitch class And since flocks at Q are rare it returns an eclectic mix of other things instead Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Whether you're browsing recent pages or viewing the results of a logbook search is specific to your current browser session and can't be exported through a URL The link you see in the URL field of your browser when you're looking at the search results ends up pointing at the logbook start page for everyone else No loss in the present case since flocks aren't momentous enough as glitches go to earn specific logbook mentions Only individual logbook entries and comments on them can be linked to directly Their URLs can be captured for pasting by using the browser's "Copy link" function on the "Link" button in the entry heading https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ for the feedback and information An eclectic mix indeed as sim search sees it I took a look at the array of subjects tagged with "flock" there is a wide variety of glitches making up a flock seems pretty special > Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Yes I recalled something about this from previous logbook searches seeing that my draft post returned the Home page after having pasted the URL on top of the search results even though that search URL contained the corresponding "page 1" and "page 2" appended yet switched to the Home page when pasted into the address bar Many thanks! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ ! number assigned across all Zooniverse subjects As of this seeming Trumpetfish there are many subjects that fit the subclass definition each having a different subject id Yes Trumpetfish seems to be still around to date as is the case with many other classes and subclasses Regards https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/102358/ The glitches visible in the strain channel are classic multi arch Scattered Light the kind that was still common during most of the third observing run before it got fixed in January The auxiliary channel which monitors the light circulating in the X arm represented by the few parts per million of it which make it through the mirror coatings on the end test mass and then get captured by the optics of the transmission monitoring system didn't witness it on this occasion The present S is a counterpart to S https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429011/ Nice catch! This and similar subjects mostly from Hanford with brief sometimes repeating noise near and or around Hz are None Of The Above Sometimes we call them "Pirate Ships" by a superficial analogy with the old Virgo O glitch class of that name At Hanford they are caused by beam jitter they show up when the laser beam already wobbles sideways a little at the point where it enters the first vacuum chamber The subset near Hz got almost completely fixed in October the others still occur occasionally They are relatively rare They may yet earn a formal glitch class proposal once we've collected enough examples https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429184/ Another kind of None Of The Above These require a glance at the Similarity Search tool tab ended https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429187/ To clarify this is primarily a gold standard example of Repeating Blips intended to familiarize volunteers in the level workflow with cases where groups of individual glitchlets need to be treated as a whole and where it is essential to look at the fourth frame and take in the whole picture And I agree on the central constituent blip being slightly mis shapen because it is coincidentally blended with a bit of unrelated lower frequency noise In some cases ancient subjects that had already been uploaded once before the Gravity Spy tools existed to serve as gold standard examples were uploaded a second time later as ordinary subjects with new subject numbers and were then also added to the Similarity Search tool's database Thus Sim Search won't find the present subject under its original number but a search for the character subject id uniqueid IdrpGAG37s will succeed and will find the copy with subject number Note that the image was reprocessed for this purpose In the newer copy the image title mentions the first observing run O explicitly What's less cool from a LIGO engineer's point of view is that this has been the most common type of glitch at Livingston since the beginning of the fourth observing run in May and it is still not clear how exactly these glitches arise We no longer get the sort of multi arch Scattered Light that was common in past years and that's illustrated in the Field Guide that sort was root caused in late tab The two arches are separated by a darker band covering Hz punctuated by three evenly spaced streaks tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk that's a region where there's a lot of always present stationary background noise which gets suppressed before our images are created So it's a new variant of lower frequency Scattered Light but it's unclear where the scattering happens at the corner station or near one of the two test masses at the ends of the arms and it's unclear what the reflecting item is that's moving relative to the test masses https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Huh so if I understand it correctly something is moving which causes the laser to move slightly thus registering as a "quake" I don't know the appropiate terminolgy sorry and you don't yet know what exactly is moving? Something weird happened here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Yes! We're living on a restless planet Even aside from earthquakes strong enough to be felt the ground beneath our feet is always in motion at speeds of up to about a micrometer per second caused by a mix of weak distant earthquakes wind driven ocean wave activity human activity plus gusts of wind leaning on building walls which then lean on the pillars which support them which then causes the floor under the pillars to tilt a little LIGO's vacuum chambers and the beam tubes connecting them along with anything attached to the walls of the vacuum vessels follow these ground motions Inside four of the large vacuum chambers at each site there are the test masses in their four stage "quad" pendulum suspensions mounted on a three stage internal seismic isolation structure mounted in turn on a hydraulic external pre isolation For some pictures of the hardware see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk So the test masses move a whole lot less than everything around them Between the polished mirror coated front surfaces of the test masses in each arm the main laser beams are circulating Tiny imperfections of the coatings cause a tiny fraction of the laser light to be scattered out of the beams in arbitrary directions Most of the stray light hits one of many baffles and is absorbed A tiny fraction of the stray light however may hit something reflective attached to the walls which are moving relative to the test masses A tiny fraction of the reflected light may hit the nearest test mass again and get scattered back to interfere with the main beam This fraction is what ultimately shows up as glitches If the stray light path length was constant it wouldn't be a problem the backscattered light may be out of phase with the main beam but that's no different from one test mass being a tiny wee little bit in the wrong place which would be automatically corrected But since the reflecting item would be moving relative to the test mass the stray light path length will also change and the phase relationship between the backscattered light and the main beam will change If the stray light path length changes by say s which is approximately laser wavelengths per second we'll get visible noise at about Hz Moreover multiple reflections can cause the stray light path to be traversed multiple times and then we'll also get visible noise at higher frequencies stacks of parallel arches The top of an arch always corresponds to the moment when the reflecting item was moving fastest in one direction or the other relative to the test mass At moments when the motion stops and turns around the arches descend off the bottom of our images The hunt for the causes involves careful analysis of videos of the near infrared light and actively shaking the beam tubes and measuring the effects both with accelerometers mounted on the beam tubes and chambers and in the light that ultimately reaches the detection photodiodes One recent logbook entry among many is LLO tab LIGO Livingston's X end test mass in its suspension center seen from rear left to its right is the suspended reaction mass with circular electrostatic actuator traces plated on it the angular structure on the left is the Arm Cavity Baffle All of the illumination captured here by the camera comes from stray laser light ! LLO ETMX quad Those gold plated electrostatic traces used to be the reflecting item responsible for the classic multi arch Scattered Light glitches during past observing runs This has been addressed since January by more carefully steering the suspensions to keep the distance between each test mass and the reaction mass behind it very nearly constant Any remaining glitches from this path would now occur below Hz where we won't see them in our subject images Looking a little further to the left with the test mass out of view beyond the right edge we now have the Arm Cavity Baffle on the right the cryopump baffle with two glints on its right edge left of center and a on the left a rather bright double glint off a spool piece where there's a large gate valve in the X arm beam tube The corner station would be km further away at rear left ! LLO glints near the end of the X arm Images from the LIGO logbooks courtesy Caltech MIT LIGO Laboratory tab The cryopump baffle is unlikely to be "it" they used to vibrate quite a lot in the presence of elevated ground motion levels and they were responsible for a lot of glitches during O but steps have since been taken to prevent them from vibrating The spool piece might be "it" but this has neither been proven nor ruled out yet The changes in the light path length implied by the frequencies of our arches seem a bit too large for it the spool piece shouldn't be able to move that much Hope this helps a little! By the way note that we don't see the main beam in these images There are more than kW of laser light circulating along earch arm between the reflecting surfaces of the input and end test masses but everything is happening inside a hard vacuum Thus there are next to no air molecules anywhere between the test masses that would scatter some light out of the beam towards the camera as they would if the beam was travelling in air https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ This is a rather common form that Scattered Light glitches from Hanford have been taking during the ongoing fourth observing run No well formed arches just wavy more or less parallel bits and fragments at frequencies mostly between and Hz sometimes with additional pieces between and Hz The band between and Hz tends to appear dark in most of our images It is blanketed by loud stationary noise which gets suppressed before our spectrogram images are created Only the loudest glitches manage to exceed the background noise in this band and show up there as well https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423062/ Very cool! So a lot of parts reflect just not into the recieving sensor? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Yes a lot of things inside the vacuum vessels are shiny and reflective One can't simply paint everything flat black paints don't go well with vacuum Paint molecules would evaporate drift around and settle somewhere else even on the test masses where we absolutely don't want them The baffles get special coatings of non smooth light absorbing materials and even then their edges can still reflect some light But the total area of the large vacuum chambers and long beam tubes is just too much to treat it all in this way That said the mirrors which are meant to reflect light in the intended directions are of exceedingly high quality and almost all of the light does go where it is meant to go The coatings on the end test masses reflect more than of the laser light! And the few parts per million that get through these coatings aren't wasted They are captured by additional optics behind the test masses and are used to measure the circulating light power and the beam position and angle https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Very cool! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3422466/ Baby koi school https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423913/ School of melted blips https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423915/ Scattered light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423919/ School koi plus ? Wheatgrass https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423921/ Wheatgrass https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3423922/ Lighthouse blip in searches fitting the other requirements so I included them in my L O collection These happen both in O4a and O4b sometimes in reverse port formation receding in a slant downwards to the left side of the spectrogram towards the "bow These morphologies happen to be also present in both collections by L ER O4a Cairn At this point I am unsure as to what is expected from Cairn O in this regard how asymmetrical the shape can be As a gold subject shows this pattern I feel that the description mound and alike are not exact being a certain mirror symmetry expected Real cairns range from perfectly symmetrical structures to crumbled or dispersed collections of rocks so perhaps a mound does not describe all the asymmetrical variations appearing in Q value and sometimes Q value Ongoing Question prominent lines to form a Cairn shape? For example a one line subject is gold subject In my opinion a cairn should need several prominent elements piled up not just a slightly curved single line Hence do we consider the very faint lines as defining elements? One possibility I've been mulling over and which may turn out to be wrong is that Cairns might be another part of the same population as Vibration Eruptions tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 1009409?comment where in the latter case the reflecting item the cryopump baffles used to be the prime suspect would be vibrating with larger amplitude thus upconverting the noise to higher frequencies at the culmination and as a byproduct also raising the decay phase which lasts a few seconds to frequencies above Hz where it doesn't get completely drowned out by the stationary background noise Like Cairns Vibration Eruptions attract renderings at a variety of Q values and they are roughly equally rare In this light it is interesting that you've picked up three in between subjects that I would be inclined to file under Vibration Eruption ! This is a good question and I don't know the answer After one of the hundreds of feedback control loops that normally cooperate to maintain a good lock had failed outright when one camera monitoring the beam alignment had stopped working there were multiple unusual things going on at once By the time the present subject was recorded a couple minutes later the Livingston interferometer had already drifted so far from its intended working point that a lockloss was less than seconds away Bits and pieces of this wandering line are visible in a number of subjects from the surrounding minutes tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk I haven't seen anything similar to it in any Livingston O subjects recorded in more normal conditions Do watch out though for a Wandering Line undulating more slowly in a few dozen Hanford O subjects from last January https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3064584/ Yes to fixes applied a few years ago most of it nowadays happens below the Hz bottom edge of our spectrograms we only get to see the topmost parts of the action https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424979/ NOTA is fine when something doesn't want to fit into the available classes This subject shows a coincidental mix of two different independent glitches The tall central feature with hints of "lighthouse" decorations could be called a Blip although it's a bit of a stretch if it had been louder it would turn into a kind of Extremely Loud The "wheatgrass" surrounding it below Hz is a form of Scattered Light rendered as rows of beatnote pulses here because this subject was processed with very fine time resolution at the expense of very coarse frequency resolution The "fins" of a Koi Fish would look somewhat similar but more symmetric and at slightly higher frequencies https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ The raw data are recorded at a rate of samples per second so frequencies up to Hz could be extracted with some distortion and up to a little beyond Hz in sufficient quality to create images like ours this isn't normally done here since it costs extra memory and processing time and most glitches don't need it I don't have a timestamp for the present subject so I can't produce another image of this particular Whistle even though the raw data from the first three observing runs are public by now but see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2079928?comment page for some other examples and illustrations! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ Another great question! Some old examples aside it is safe to assume that every Gravity Spy subject from recent and ongoing observing runs contains a glitch or rarely a real gravitational wave chirp something that exceeded the ever present background noise levels by at least a factor of But that Something isn't always visible in the resulting image The Gravity Spy tools tab Watch out for other NotNoGlitch subjects There are many with reported peak frequencies around or around Hz betraying a violin mode origin quite a few from Hanford at or Hz which tend to belong into a proposed new class tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk some from Hanford at or Hz and more from Livingston at Hz which belong into another propopsed class tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk and some others https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ What happens when a participant chooses NOTA? Does it get sent to a higher level for further inspection? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ I just checked the datasets at gwosc to see if I could get the data from there but it looks like data from January to November is missing entirely? Why is this? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ First of all This is an extraneous subject there must exist another where the obvious extremely loud glitch appears properly centered I haven't seen it yet but it would probably look somewhat like tab recorded a day and a half earlier The difference in appearance is due to rendering choices coarse vs fine time resolution combined with fine vs coarse frequency resolution Why do we get such extraneous off center subjects? Mostly because the glitch detection software inspects minute long chunks of data at a time setting to work in near real time whenever another minute's worth of data has become available The "outskirts" of a loud glitch near the end of one chunk can then cause another spurious detection at the beginning of the next chunk as in this case or the onset of a loud glitch near the beginning of a fresh chunk can already have caused a spurious detection at the end of the preceding chunk Next This one did not cause a lockloss we see clean data with just the usual amount of faint random background noise everywhere in the right half of the fourth frame But similar glitches are among the loudest that a LIGO interferometer can with luck survive without losing its lock tab is one of the loudest such I've seen at an SNR above And even louder ones can cause a lockloss E this one did some seconds beyond the " s" right edge of the fourth frame ! frame What causes this kind of extremely loud glitches? Ultimately earthquakes or thunderclaps or very strong gusts of wind which despite the multi stage seismic isolation manage to cause one or more of the mirror suspensions to shake The feedback control loops which keep the arm length difference "DARM" constant to within a picometer a millionth of a micrometer and those which keep the test masses mirrors at their proper angles to allow the laser light to bounce back and forth between them more than a hundred times operate in a mode with limited actuation strength and low noise once the lock has been acquired They can compensate and damp some amount of unwanted motion but not a lot When more force would be needed than is available things will momentarily depart from the proper working point resulting in a sudden LOT of noise in the data and a loudspeaker in the control room will automatically issue a verbal alert like "EX saturation!" to the operator With luck acting a little longer with the limited force available may still suffice to recover from the disturbance or it may not the lock may be lost a fast shutter closes within milliseconds to protect the detection photodiodes the input laser power is ramped down the remaining circulating laser light ends up in beam dumps and the lock would need to be reacquired slowly The saturation and lockloss illustrated above at 19T was caused by an earthquake and goes with LLO tab https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ In case of a no glitch should I use the tools to see if this is really the case and then report as NOTA if there is something? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ I'll have a look at the tools I assume these should only be used when the glitch class isn't clear? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ In the long run yes or it may just be kept around until all the newly discovered glitch classes have been studied sufficiently to re train the Machine Learning and to make some of them official so that further submissions can then mark them as "one of the above" And in any case NOTA ensures that more people are going to get a look! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ Because the first Observing Run of Advanced LIGO ended on and the second started on GWOSC only holds published data tab Engineering Runs are thus excluded weekly maintenance periods are excluded routine half hour calibration measurement periods are excluded and of course there are no data from times when the observatories weren't observing g recovering from a lockloss or weren't even running because of lengthy upgrades tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2800503?comment between observing runs https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ You mention SNR what is this a measurement of? Anywhere I can read up on this? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ It's up to you how deeply you want to delve into each subject! Sometimes Similarity Search provides insights that aren't easy to come by in other ways Personally I am going to some extremes but I certainly don't expect everybody else to do so I will run a "NotNoGlitch" subject through a similarity search for result immediately based on the character identifier which I can already access while classifying just to see whether it belongs under Violin Modes or Low Frequency Lines or somewhere else Otherwise I'll just make a note of the subject number to return to it later I would usually add a subject to an appropriate collection only after it has been returned as a result from a small similarity search starting from another subject by which time I would also have written down the peak frequency and other metadata and eyeballed an approximate timestamp to within minutes or so and then I feed the collected subject's number back into another sim search to keep my to do queues populated I also keep track of how often each subject has appeared as a sim search result In this way I can gradually build collections of the most representative subjects of each kind Cascades of many small searches asking for rather fewer than results each time tend to work much better for exploring an underlying populations than doing only a few searches asking for many results Of course the tool being image based mixes up all the NotNoGlitch subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424992/ Signal to background Noise Ratio or in this case glitch noise level divided by background noise level https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ The "date" stamps of old subjects are dummy values reflecting the date on which the upload script was last modified Only since the fourth observing run do we have the real event date available through the nfo button Admittedly this is a little confusing but then almost all old subjects have been deactivated from the workflows in order to focus on the new material except for the gold standard subjects and for a selection of Whistles from O to make up for a total lack of Whistles from O so far The present subject dates from the first observing run and was uploaded to Zooniverse in October after results from a pilot phase of the budding project had been evaluated Subjects from later runs have the run number embedded in their titles after the observatory name https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ To be frank at the moment the Machine Learning is all over the place The glitch mix coming from the LIGO observatories during the ongoing fourth observing run differs very much from anything we've seen before and from everything the ML had previously been trained for We still have recognizable Blips and Koi Fish but Scattered Light looks very different now and there are many completely new things tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk and some new things that look deceptively similar to old glitch classes that haven't reoccurred in years or whose causes have been completely eliminated in the course of observatory upgrades And changing anything in the ML takes time tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3369772?comment One fairly recent paper is Y Wu al Advancing Glitch Classification in Gravity Spy Multi view Fusion with Attention based Machine Learning Just a question for my own understanding I'm aware that a fair amount of browser side Zooniverse state both PFE and FEM is cached in session storage Are cookies currently also being used for anything aside from authentication and statistics gathering? Or would this be the first use of cookies for maintaining functional state? Why I am asking is When a volunteer switches among several devices or among several different browsers browser profiles on one device session state for which the single source of truth is on the server side will be fetched and cached and the new session will be in sync with where the previous session had left off But cookies won't carry over This might cause surprises If there's already other functional state that's kept in cookies then I'd expect fewer surprises But if not then a solution based on the existing per user per project project preferences stored server side and cached browser side might be preferable in the long term so as to have all such features work in similar ways The server side project preferences already remember in which workflow of the project I've been active most recently and if I'm not mistaken they are already being fetched by both frontends when a classifier is launched so the information would be available to the frontends it's just not being used at the moment https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ I'll have a look at the paper you sent very much for the quick and helpful answers! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3424985/ Fair enough https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/418228/ So 95440075's glitch is times louder ? clearer? brighter? than the background? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ Yes that's it "Louder" is probably the best word Astronomers speak of a binary neutron star merger as a " standard siren tab The SNR is computed in relation to the small random background fluctuations not in relation to the DC light level Also ever present stationary noise a lot of it esp at low frequencies but also at a number of fixed higher frequencies is removed before considering the random background and computing SNRs Here's a plot of yesterday's stationary background noise levels from the detector status summary page for the day tab ! IGWN sensitivity Some LIGO noise features you can find in there include suspension noise near and near and Hz a mostly subtracted out bunch of calibration lines around Hz the Hz mains frequency the violin modes of the beam splitter suspension near Hz and those of the test mass suspensions near Hz and multiples thereof Virgo's fundamental violin modes show up near Hz and multiples and Virgo's Hz mains subtraction has been doing a good job leaving only a modest peak in the violet curve The steep overall rise on the left is mostly due to a combination of seismic noise thermal noise radiation pressure noise on the test masses and residual motion of the suspensions The less steep rise on the right is shot noise from the detection photodiodes picking up the incoming light in discrete quanta already mitigated as far as possible by quantum squeezing tab https en wikipedia org wiki Squeezed states of light https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/ What causes 60hz glitches to appear even when mitigated? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3425035/

https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ I ve updated the GitHub PR to explain how a SameSite cookie protects against accidentally loading the wrong workflow when following a link from an email or external site https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ As a matter of interest maybe to others like myself what on earth is ConvNN? I have seen it when doing sim searches and should have asked this years ago It is something I doubt I will ever need to use but I am interested where it fits in to the whole AI ML scheme of things Please is there a VERY basic explanation? No hurry! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Sorry to hear it I have passed the message on to the person who developed the promotion system and hope to have a fix soon https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ When I check though it says you are in level Could you reload the site and see what levels are unlocked? Or is it promotion to level that's not working? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ Promotion to level is not working https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ A Convolutional Neural Network tab The simulated cells are arranged in layers The given image is divided into arrays of overlapping little squares The image data in each square are fed into one of the cells in the first layer Each of these input cells reacts to left right or up down or diagonal gradients brightness variations in its input square this is the "convolutional" part The outputs of the first layer cells in all sorts of combinations are processed further by the next layers Each successive layer is able to detect more complicated combinations of image traits straight or curved edges small or large uniform regions arches parallel streaks fuzziness Nessie coils After some four or five or six intermediate layers the final output layer consists of one cell for each glitch class or whatever one is trying to classify The one that "shouts most loudly" determines the label that will be attached to the image and how loudly it "shouts" compared to the others provides a confidence estimate During training the connections among the layers are strengthened or weakened at random until the outputs delivered on the training images agree reasonably well with the intended classifications This too aims to imitate how we understand learning to happen in real brains Hope this is suitably basic!
