https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ I ve updated the GitHub PR to explain how a SameSite cookie protects against accidentally loading the wrong workflow when following a link from an email or external site https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3206987/ As a matter of interest maybe to others like myself what on earth is ConvNN? I have seen it when doing sim searches and should have asked this years ago It is something I doubt I will ever need to use but I am interested where it fits in to the whole AI ML scheme of things Please is there a VERY basic explanation? No hurry! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Sorry to hear it I have passed the message on to the person who developed the promotion system and hope to have a fix soon https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ When I check though it says you are in level Could you reload the site and see what levels are unlocked? Or is it promotion to level that's not working? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ Promotion to level is not working https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ A Convolutional Neural Network tab The simulated cells are arranged in layers The given image is divided into arrays of overlapping little squares The image data in each square are fed into one of the cells in the first layer Each of these input cells reacts to left right or up down or diagonal gradients brightness variations in its input square this is the "convolutional" part The outputs of the first layer cells in all sorts of combinations are processed further by the next layers Each successive layer is able to detect more complicated combinations of image traits straight or curved edges small or large uniform regions arches parallel streaks fuzziness Nessie coils After some four or five or six intermediate layers the final output layer consists of one cell for each glitch class or whatever one is trying to classify The one that "shouts most loudly" determines the label that will be attached to the image and how loudly it "shouts" compared to the others provides a confidence estimate During training the connections among the layers are strengthened or weakened at random until the outputs delivered on the training images agree reasonably well with the intended classifications This too aims to imitate how we understand learning to happen in real brains Hope this is suitably basic! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426520/ Among the various O "NotNoGlitch" subjects a few hundred mostly from Hanford O4b stand out They have peak frequencies near or near Hz and are readily tied to logbook entries about rung up violin modes The Machine Learning has been calling them No Glitch and indeed there's nothing much to see yet Omicron had triggered on them as excess noise with SNRs above or else they wouldn't exist as Gravity Spy subjects But it turns out that they don't actually represent glitches in the strain channel They represent elevated stationary noise levels in DARM and strain varying only gradually on time scales of minutes to hours They really originate as glitches in the glitch detection itself Thus I'm documenting them here as a distinct subclass of Violin Mode Harmonics Proposed Name LIGO O Invisible Violins ID of proposer Date of proposal Reference subjects for Classifier and Field Guide S holotype linked above S S S ! frame showing the second frames Short description Nothing at all stands out visually Minor unrelated noise may be present The peak frequencies accessible through Similarity Search tab Characteristics As above SNRs rarely exceed All Q value choices can occur Overlapping pairs of subjects are unusually common see below Hash tags a Collections NB the metadata links do not work at present pending a DYCWMI tool bugfix but will work once the tool has been fixed no training set at this time since the current Machine Learning doesn't take Omicron metadata into account Bulk collections growing H ER O4a Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er a invisible violins link to its metadata tab L ER O4a Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er a invisible violins link to its metadata tab H ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant h er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab L ER O4b Invisible Violins tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant l er b invisible violins link to its metadata tab Collaborators Remarks In fact not only is there an unusual excess of overlapping pairs of subjects these pairs also straddle full second boundaries at one minute intervals The examples from all come just before or just after a GPS second that fell seconds after a multiple of Those from all happened seconds after a multiple of On the other hand the seconds periodicity tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk of the Pizzicato glitches from O has disappeared completely Example pairs more will keep turning up from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab and from between and UTC tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab tab What must have been happening here is that Omicron in the presence of a rung up violin mode or other loud stationary narrowband noise tends to trigger near the end of its current seconds chunk of data and then again near the beginning of the next seconds chunk Sometimes only one member of such a pair of triggers will exceed the SNR > threshold for creating a Gravity Spy subject Sometimes both would remain too faint to show up here https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ So what to do about these triggers? Are they useful? Are they necessary? Could we do without them? The observatory operators and the data quality team on their weekly shifts don't need them rung up violin modes are reported in other more direct ways They do add some spice to the Gravity Spy volunteer experience One more sort of thing that requires taking a closer look and extracting the peak frequency using the Similarity Search tool tab It is likely that they could be avoided by padding the minute long data chunks on which Omicron operates with shoulders of at least seconds on both sides my experience whilst working with the glitch plotter tab So it may be better to keep things as they are and live with these "glitches" It's worth noting that the Virgo team had encountered a very similar issue at the beginning of O tab O fallout as Gravity Spy subjects ER LHO LHO tab O4a LHO 04ff LHO tab LLO briefly very visible just before a lockloss see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk LHO and following ITMY mode and none O4b LLO 15f LLO tab LHO LHO tab LHO LHO tab I have not yet seen any subjects from subequent episodes LHO LHO tab LLO LLO tab LLO 16ff LLO tab LLO 31ff LLO tab LLO LLO tab modes https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3428271/ The images fed to the GravitySpy ML ConvNN day in day out while the observatories are Observing are the same that then get uploaded to Zooniverse as subjects for us to inspect except that the ML gets to "view" all four frames at once side by side and without the title texts colourmap axis tick marks and labels only the four spectrogram images themselves For re training purposes it would be fed a set of around a hundred such images carefully selected and believed to be representative of a single new glitch class In reality it's somewhat more complicated The set is split up randomly into a larger part used for the training phase and a smaller part for testing validation Then the current training subset is run through the neural network adjusting the cell connections in the process and the outcome is evaluated on the current test subset while keeping the connections fixed And then this is repeated with a new random splitting of the given subject set many times until the results no longer improve in further iterations The sort of language oriented AI that has been getting headlines in the last year and a half ChatGPT and friends works completely differently though The only commonalities are that they also run on computers and also need to be trained But they require vastly larger amounts of training data and existing Large Language Models have been trained on data of sometimes extremely dubious quality not to mention copyright infringements on a global scale it I began a collection on these events https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ Pretty catch! The title subject is a rare Q rendering of a flock as is The remainder of the sim search results is something of a mixed bunch Since the choice of Q value has such a large effect on the general texture of the resulting subject images the Similarity Search tool tends to be more sensitive to the Q value than to the glitch class And since flocks at Q are rare it returns an eclectic mix of other things instead Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Whether you're browsing recent pages or viewing the results of a logbook search is specific to your current browser session and can't be exported through a URL The link you see in the URL field of your browser when you're looking at the search results ends up pointing at the logbook start page for everyone else No loss in the present case since flocks aren't momentous enough as glitches go to earn specific logbook mentions Only individual logbook entries and comments on them can be linked to directly Their URLs can be captured for pasting by using the browser's "Copy link" function on the "Link" button in the entry heading https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3428755/ for the feedback and information An eclectic mix indeed as sim search sees it I took a look at the array of subjects tagged with "flock" there is a wide variety of glitches making up a flock seems pretty special > Unfortunately the logbook software provides no way of linking to a list of search results Yes I recalled something about this from previous logbook searches seeing that my draft post returned the Home page after having pasted the URL on top of the search results even though that search URL contained the corresponding "page 1" and "page 2" appended yet switched to the Home page when pasted into the address bar Many thanks! Last year there were occasional hiccups with the subject upload process which resulted in repeated upload attempts and thus in accidental duplications and it has not been feasible to clean up completely afterwards The present glitch is one of that happened between and at Hanford cause unknown and not related to locklosses but nearly each of them was uploaded to Zooniverse five times under five different subject numbers without making it into the Gravity Spy tools before finally being successfully uploaded a sixth time The good and usable subjects from those days have numbers 9636xxxx the earlier 9287xxxx through 9343xxxx should be considered as extraneous duplicates If we were to remove them from Zooniverse now we would also orphan the associated Talk threads and produce inconsistencies in any collections containing them The usable version of the present subject is tab As to how to deal with the duplicates I would frown at them flag them as such by adding them to suitable marker collections and move on to the next subject There's also a small handful of subjects showing other kinds of glitches of which two or more copies exist in the Similarity Seach database and these can produce a different nondescript error when one asks for fewer results than the number of copies There used to be many more during O many subjects had been ingested four or five times and there was one that had got uploaded more than a thousand times those had been cleared out at one point leaving only one representative subject of each glitch Clearing out the few that exist at the present time would require a disproportionate amount of manual effort so we've left them alone https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ oki thanks for clarification! Definitely not by brute forcing subject IDs matching right? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Yes well observed you'll see this in a number of ancient subjects If I am not mistaken the reason is that back then well before my time the normalized noise energy was fed into the colormap as is whereas more recent subjects use the logarithm of the normalized energy which will show some finer glitch details as well as the random background more clearly Noise levels within a single subject image can vary by five orders of magnitude even after the removal of stationary noise "whitening" during preprocessing https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429884/ One of our veteran volunteers who is currently taking a break from Zooniverse had collected almost all of these two hundred something Hz glitch subjects as they come up whilst classifying Once our systematic similarity searches across the good ones found no further examples it was a matter of looking at each of the good ones in turn find its exact copies in the twenty odd collection pages where twelve subject per page are displayed write down the relationships in an offline file and remove the copies from the bulk collection so this eyeball search became easier with each glitch that we had dealt with A few duplicates had been missed and only showed up later and these could be tied in by eyeballing the collection of good representatives which fits on pages https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429888/ Can someone shed some light on what to classify this one please? None Of The Above is always an option whenever something doesn't want to fit easily into the available classes And this is often the case at present During the fourth observing run that's now in progress after three years of upgrades tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2800503?comment the LIGO interferometers have been producing a glitch mix that's very different from anything we had seen before Some old glitch classes still occur in recognizable forms some still occur but look different some no longer occur and quite a few completely new things tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk have been coming up The present subject comes from a brief episode on tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk when one of Livingston's feedback control loops had failed and over the course of a mere three minutes the interferometer drifted so far from its working point that the lock was lost We already see multiple things going on at once here repeating blips violin mode harmonics a wandering line While it's not at all obvious it was one of the repeating blips that triggered this subject But None Of The Above is certainly appropriate too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430118/ None Of The Above They were a completely new and unexpected thing tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk when they suddenly started happening in large numbers during three days in late May and early June https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3000650/ Well noted! Again I would recommend None Of The Above These Hz glitches were another new thing when they showed up on at Hanford and then stopped happening again at the end of the month Only such glitches seem to have been recorded too few to justify a formal glitch class proposal the cause remains a mystery Around that time there were hiccups with the uploading of subjects to the Gravity Spy tools tab The Ripples have not reoccurred in the 3rd and 4th observing runs but there are some lookalikes that have been confusing the Gravity Spy Machine Learning too https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430133/ Yet another type of None Of The Above! These mini jolts like the Hz glitches come from beam jitter when the laser beam wobbles sideways by a tiny amount already before it enters the first vacuum chamber On this particular occasion on technicians had been pulling fiber cables under the raised floors near the control room to connect a fire alarm panel The connection to these glitches was soon noted tab Why not start a collection of these? It will come in helpful There isn't a formal glitch class proposal for these jitter glitches yet but I guess there have been enough of them to justify one once we can support it with collections of representative subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3430142/ They would have been visible when they occurred on their own thanks to the energy normalization but not when anything louder was also present https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3429884/ Well observed! I would have classified two of the glitches as Virgo but was not offered that option Please clarify Susan https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ The Virgo glitch classes apply to glitch subjects from the European Virgo interferometer which used to have its own separate workflow in past years currently inactive Despite occasional visual similarities and some real analogies glitches from LIGO Hanford or Livingston won't fit into Virgo classes nor vice versa By the way whenever you spot something unusual or that raises questions in your mind please be welcome to click "Done Talk" straight away instead of "Done" browse any pre existing comments on the subject and add your own questions or remarks! When you have a general question or suggestion you can start a new thread in the most suitable of our Talk tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk boards after a quick look whether there's already an existing thread about the topic better than adding to an existing thread about something else and changing the topic And when you encounter the same kind of unusual glitch several times why not start a collection of them and bring it up for show and tell in the Talk > Collections tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk board once it seems presentable? There are quite a lot of novel glitches nowadays that won't easily fit into any existing class and representative collections will come in useful for characterizing them again for contributing! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3398363/ HI this is interesting > It has long been suspected that single dust grains which occasionally fall through the beam in one of the arms can be the cause of loud glitches Has this been happening over the years despite the vacuum chambers and clean rooms? The collection looks equally interesting bearing certain general similarities to other glitches going around so I hope that the researches will be able to add some Q scan images to look further into this https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3431042/ Yes the level workflow is currently a bit of a junk yard Part of the reason is that when the Hz transients first appeared the Gravity Spy Machine Learning unprepared for such a thing labeled almost all of them as Whistle with a high estimated confidence which caused the automated workflow preselection to assign them to the entry level or workflows when they were first uploaded to Zooniverse Once this had been noticed those subject sets were manually reassigned to level to ensure volunteers would only see them after having acquired some general experience Then when the Hz beeps first appeared the same thing happened again only compounded this time by upload issues which resulted in a large number of duplicated subjects tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3429888?comment So those also got reassigned to level Together they add up to about six hundred subjects A third factor at play is that towards the end of last year it was noticed that the Machine Learning had been systematically over estimating its own confidence This was adjusted before the second half O4b of the fourth observing run began in April this year This adjustment has affected the workflow preselection even some glitches that are "obviously" Blips or "obviously" Scattered Light now get pre labeled with low confidence or mis labeled and end up in one of the more advanced workflows in hard to predict ways One side effect of this is that the level workflow appears to be somewhat starved of subjects aside from the Hz and Hz ones and aside from the gold standard sets A fourth factor is that fresh uploads have stalled since the researchers are working on getting them restarted and catching up on the backlog Moreover Hanford had been offline for six weeks beginning in mid July to undertake repairs and didn't produce any fresh subjects during this time Once new subjects are streaming in again the picture may change a bit and level may once more offer more varied challenges Keeping fingers crossed crossed fingers https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/730/3430635/ As far as I know this mechanism has never before been conclusively proved but it is believed to have been happening at a low rate for many years yes despite all the cleaning and baking or firing of all vacuum facing surfaces before they were assembled Bear in mind that the insides of the km long beam tubes or even just their upper halves add up to a lot of surface area and they've been in an uninterrupted hard vacuum for decades thus inacessible to inspections let alone interventions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3431042/ good to know this other detail https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3431042/ Fuzzy range 30 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3431583/ A few general further thoughts sprinkled with some aux channel names The AERM PDs would witness dust events that happen not too far from one arm end but may not witness all dust events Stray light flashes from events in the middle of the arm or closer to an input end would mostly end up on the beam tube baffles and ACBs and the fraction which reaches these monitoring PDs may not rise above background noise levels When they do witness an event they'll provide a measurement of the time the particle took to traverse the beam and thus a lower limit on the beam diameter at that point The longest lasting events would come from particles passing almost centrally through the beam and fairly close to an ETM where the diameter is largest What happens in one arm won't stay in one arm When the light field in one arm is momentarily disturbed in both amplitude and phase the disturbance will couple within milliseconds into the Power Recycling Cavity into the Signal Recycling Cavity and onto the DC photodiodes and thence into the DARM loop It will then be recycled back into both arms and the DARM loop will react to the perceived displacement by acting on one designated end test mass and on the upper masses of both end test mass suspensions now causing a real deviation from the DARM working point which will be counteracted during the following tens to hundreds of milliseconds When the disturbance is strong enough one or more DARM actuators may get saturated and we'll see an even louder glitch with I expect larger noise content towards higher frequencies But DARM actuation saturations can happen for other reasons too when the DARM loop counteracts some seismic disturbance of the quad suspensions Those events the loudest glitches that are with luck survivable without losing the lock SNRs can exceed will never be witnessed by the AERM PDs So it may be useful to look not only at the two AERM PD sum channels L ASC X Y TR ERM NSUM OUT DQ but also at eight PUM coil L degree of freedom and four ESD quadrant L degree of freedom actuation channels where saturations would stand out L SUS ETM X Y L COILOUTF UL UR LL LR OUTPUT L SUS ETMX L ESDOUTF UL UR LL LR OUTPUT there are also the UIM coil L o channels but they would be unlikely to saturate without L and or L also hitting the ceiling What we can hope to glean from this is a breakdown into the subset of loud glitches with AERM PD witnesses without saturation the subset with both AERM PD witnesses and saturation the subset without AERM PD witnesses but with saturation Saturation events not involving dust should all be in the third subset Events involving dust may show up in any of the three Events in the first two subsets are likely to involve dust Plus some borderline cases without either kind of witness And then it'll be interesting whether the "GS 0" visual appearance combined with Omicron metadata esp the SNR would already allow to predict the subset to which a glitch subject belongs My current pet hypothesis which may turn out wrong is that significant noise content above Hz witnessed by extensive two sided artefacts up there will correlate with saturation events And conversely that the first subset is going to correspond to loud glitches with extensive lateral artefacts only below Hz Based on O examples I've already seen extensive artefacts above Hz tend to go with higher SNRs generally above lack thereof usually goes with SNRs below but there's a region of overlap between SNR and both morphologies can occur Some Hanford operators diligently mention saturations which come with verbal alerts in the control room in their shift reports Since they are rare on average a few per hour shift it has often been possible to tie them in with individual subjects even when I a priori know the subject timestamp only to within minutes or so These subjects consistently come with high SNRs > and broad artefacts well above Hz Unfortunately Livingston operators only rarely mention these things nowadays ground or floor motion coupling noted tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk at Hanford especially near Hz refers to noise showing up at that frequency in the gravitational strain measurement and thus with luck in our subject images and also at the same frequency and measurably correlated in several accelerometers mounted on the floor near the vacuum chambers The floor is moving by a tiny amount and the signal from which we're trying to extract gravitational wave events is wobbling by a tiny amount in lockstep with the floor motion in spite of all the sophisticated seismic isolation and suspended optics So there must be some item inside the vacuum chambers that is capable of vibrating at this frequency and that is following the floor motion and that in turn somehow couples to the circulating laser light Maybe one edge of one of the many baffles that otherwise aim to catch stray light Or maybe the laser beam spot is too close to the edge of one of the dozen odd smaller mirrors it needs to bounce off before it reaches the middle of the interferometer and branches out into the arms when that mirror then wobbles a little it might periodically clip a small part of the beam This differs somewhat from the ubiquitous scattered light glitches where the noise we get to see shows up at a higher frequency above Hz up to tens of Hz than the ground motion itself most of which happens at to less than Hz What causes the floor to sometimes vibrate at a tad over Hz isn't entirely clear yet either Such floor motion above Hz would not come from seismic activitiy it could come from pumps or from ventilation fans Hope this is makes it a little less remote! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3433257/ It may look a little lonesome here but its friends Good question and the answer is "it depends" Some types of repeating glitches of the same kind have their own dedicated classes the present subject beginning with the level workflow would fit under Repeating Blips In levels Blip would do or None Of The Above if you find it looks just too strange which is often the case nowadays After three years of upgrades tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 2800503?comment the LIGO interferometers are now producing many glitches that won't readily fit into our old classification scheme and there's a lot worth discussing here in Talk In other cases two glitches of different types occasional appear together just by a chance coincidence and in that case we would focus on the one closest to time seconds or dominant at this time Except in the level workflow The present subject is indeed rather unusual It came from an episode that lasted a mere three minutes when one of Livingston's less important feedback control loops had failed and the interferometer quickly drifted away from its intended working point And then the important loops couldn't keep up and the lock was lost For a longer story and how the glitches gradually got worse over the course of these minutes see here tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3426094/ Yes that's another of the beam jitter frequency bands https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3434569/ Never a dull moment! https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3434504/ MF? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3434509/ Medium Frequency Good grief had I never spelt this out in the old glitch class proposal? I am trying to capture the evolving nature of glitch classification, the needs for new classifications, and novel exploration of glitch origins and characteristics by citizen scientists and researchers. It has that moir appearance https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ Given the quite high signal to background noise ratio I would file this under Extremely Loud subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? Blip and LF Blip The latter by definition have a peak frequency below Hz which would also fit for the present subject but they are less tall than Blips or Tomtes My rule of thumb is that an LF Blip must be shorter than "two octaves" at most a factor of between bottom and top ends of their bright yellow parts g fitting between and Hz or between and Hz twice the distance between tick marks on the All our workflows benefit from volunteer input and you're very welcome to work in any of those you have unlocked by now I regularly cycle through levels to myself with occasional excursions into level You can also take some time off classifying strange new glitches of which many refuse to fit into the existing classes and instead focus on a single kind of glitch for a while using the Similarity Search tool tab The Gravity Spy Machine Learning as currently trained can handle only a minority of the glitches that have been coming out of the LIGO interferometers during the ongoing fourth observing run The glitch mix has changed a lot compared to the earlier runs How subjects are assigned to workflows depends on these currently rather flawed ML labels As a result we're getting to see surprising subjects in each of the workflows and levels and have become trickier while level isn't much harder to deal with than level now A lot of things that aren't Whistles had gotten mis labeled as such and ended up in the level and workflows until they were manually moved to level which has become a bit of a junkyard therefore A lot of things that resemble Power Lines but aren't are sitting in levels and with very few real Power Line glitches hiding among them Other novelties have been sprinkled all over the map Diligent eyes and brains are needed everywhere to make sense of the mess And no single workflow provides anything like a representative picture of the whole each is biased in its own way Be advised also that many subjects are currently assigned to more than one workflow if you cycle through workflows you may meet the same subject more than once https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3469427/ Yes part of this tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk story from August Can you find it in the illustrated timeline there?     I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

ChatCompletion(id='chatcmpl-AIO0AL6QtRnVLstb2RXUmKG7NuMVG', choices=[Choice(finish_reason='stop', index=0, logprobs=None, message=ChatCompletionMessage(content='1. **Novel Glitch Classes Proposed in Talk Dataset 2:**\n   - **Fuzzy Range Glitch**: This is identified as a new class or subclass in Talk Dataset 2. Mention of the "fuzzy range" is recurrent, suggesting a type of glitch that does not neatly fit into previously known categories. It is described with characteristics such as lacking the "tell tale eyes" of Power Line glitches and often appearing in contexts where traditional glitch categories fail to apply. This glitch seems to be associated with a variety of frequencies and is frequently mentioned across different subjects and conditions.\n     - URL references: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3462091/, https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3462098/\n\n2. **Concerns Regarding Existing Glitch Classes:**\n   - **Misclassification Issues**: In Talk Dataset 2, there are mentions of ongoing issues with misclassifications, particularly with the Power Line glitch. subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was must be shorter than "two octaves" at most a factor of between bottom and top ends of their bright yellow parts g fitting between and Hz or between and Hz twice the distance between tick marks on the subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change! It has that moir appearance https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ Given the quite high signal to background noise ratio I would file this under Extremely Loud subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle 

    Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest.     I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

This descriptor suggests that the glitch has characteristics of appearing momentarily and then disappearing, much like the historical mystery of the Marie Celeste ship. This proposed class reflects a glitch that is transient and unexplained, making it distinct from previously recognized persistent or cyclic glitches.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3463362/\n   - **Terracotta Warriors**: Mentioned as emerging from observations, this glitch class is notably named after the famous Terracotta Warriors, suggesting a glitch appearance that is structured and aligned, resembling the historical formation of the warriors. This indicates a regular, possibly linear pattern of glitches that stand out distinctly from more random or scattered glitch types.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3463598/\n\n2. **Concerns Regarding Existing Glitch Classes:**\n   - **Mislabeling in Levels and Workflows**: Participants in Talk Dataset 2 express concerns about glitches that are mislabeled, particularly noting that many could not be accurately classified within the existing glitch categories. They point out that erroneous labeling across different levels of analysis has led to a "junkyard" of misidentified glitches, which complicates further analysis and proper classification of new data.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3469427/\n   - **Ambiguity in Low Frequency and High Frequency Blip Definitions**: There is also a discussion about the distinction between Blips and Low Frequency Blips, where the community debates on the frequency range that should define each class effectively. This confusion affects the accuracy of classifying and understanding glitch behaviors.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3459088/\n\n3. **Emerging Questions Related to Glitch Classes and Technical Aspects:**\n   - **Questions on Workflow Classification Consistency**: There\'s a noticeable query about the consistency in how glitches are assigned to workflows, reflecting a deeper inquiry into the machine learning models used in classifying glitches. Participants are trying to understand why certain glitches appear in unexpected workflows, which could indicate underlying flaws or necessary improvements in classification algorithms.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3469427/\n   - **Inquiry into Glitch Characteristics and Sensor Responses**: Participants question the sensor reactions to different glitch types, especially when unexpected patterns like "Visible Violins" appear. They seek to understand how such patterns are related to the actual mechanical or environmental influences on the LIGO detectors.\n     - URL: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/\n\n4. **Specific Hypotheses About Glitch Origins in Talk Dataset 2:**\n   - **Environmental Influences on Sensor Reactions**: A hypothesis is discussed regarding ground motion near the sensors, possibly influencing the appearance of glitches. subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change! It has that moir appearance https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ Given the quite high signal to background noise ratio I would file this under Extremely Loud subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato 
    - Power Line (60 Hz) 
    - Repeating Blips 
    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte 
    - Uncategorized_Glitches 
    - Violin Mode Harmonic 
    - Wandering Line 
    - Whistle

    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed.
