Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

    The following data are from citizen scientists identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. The data originally were in a pandas dataframe of two columns. The first column was the "comment" text and the second was the "URL" affiliated with that comment. I am trying to capture the evolving nature of glitch classification, the needs for new classifications, and novel exploration of glitch origins and characteristics by citizen scientists and researchers. subclass "grounded whipnose anglerfish tab above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ In levels these can in fact be classified as Wandering Line The original Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was Wandering Line subjects from the first observing run were caused in a different way but that'll be a matter of different populations subclasses I would still continue to use the good old glitch class here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change! here In levels where Wandering Line is not available NOTA is of course the best choice https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455707/ The electromagnetic coils and elecrostatic devices acting on the test mass suspensions have different modes of operation A higher power but noisy mode used during lock acquisition when larger motions of the swinging masses need to be damped and a low power low noise mode to which they're transitioned once the motions have died down and we want to proceed to Observing In the low noise mode there's only limited force available to deal with any disturbances from earthquakes or wind gusts etc Trying to counteract a sudden stronger disturbance can reach the limits of this mode A loudspeaker in the control room will then warn the operators that there has been a saturation of the actuators of one or more suspensions What happens next is a matter of luck Sometimes applying the maximum available force for a little longer can bring the suspension back under full control and we'll get "only" an Extremely Loud glitch of the grounded anglerfish kind SNRs above one thousand typically and can continue Observing Sometimes the effort is futile and we lose the lock and need to close the shutters before the photodiodes get damaged by a bright flash of out of control laser light That was the case on this occasion We still get to see part of the extremely loud glitch at the right edge stage left of frame but then the data stream ends abruptly an instant later resulting in the extensive moir pattern during the image processing There have also been cases where the lock survived for a number of seconds after the saturation and then was lost In these cases the result will be a mostly very dark subject with a bright "mast" on the right of frame but little moir And conversely sometimes we get subjects where we see the moir but any loud associated glitch that might exist is off stage past the seconds edge where we can't see it https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455739/ I thought that under snr was koifish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3455698/ Not No Glitch 93Hz Ground motion coupling? present event may have been caused by ground motion in the Hz band there's a little spike at about the right time ! LIGO ground motion Hz The plots attached to LHO for this timestamp show the coarse corrections sent to the electromagnets acting on the penultimate masses veering off first these are the four sets of wiggly curves on the left side click on the image below to open a large version in a new browser tab Only milliseconds later does the fine correction shoot off that's sent to the electrostatic devices acting on the X end test mass the second plot from the bottom on the right this is the signal that's normally responsible for keeping the arm length difference constant to within about a picometre a millionth of a micrometre ! test mass actuation at LHO 10T UTC The implication is that during those milliseconds the test masses were still unaffected The end of this brief time must mark the moment when the disturbance of the upper masses had travelled down the slender suspension fibers and started to affect the test masses The lock was lost about milliseconds later when the corrections could no longer keep up with suppressing the motions https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3461469/ P S Looking closely at the top right plot of H LSC DARM IN DQ the measured variation of the arm length difference on picometre scales from which the correction signal is derived we see a whole lot of quite regular wiggles about wiggles during those milliseconds thus one wiggle every milliseconds or about per second that's visible violins now for a change!
